He will learn a lot from this tour.
England has made some changes in the coaching staff.
The appointment of Sri Lanka batsman Mahela Jayawardene as a consultant for test matches could be a masterstroke.
He is one of the best players and he will bring a lot of experience, having played in every situation and against all types of attack.
Paul Collingwood comes in for the white-ball leg of the tour and will bring both energy and relentless ambition.
I always believed he was born to be involved in international cricket, whether as a player or a coach, and like Mahela, he has an eye for the game.
Sometimes, new voices in the locker room, even if they convey messages that have been conveyed before, can bring fresh air to the team.
Colly Durham's team-mate Ben Stokes is rested for the one-day matches, Root was given a similar break against Australia and I have no problem with that.
Although not all agree, coaches and managers don't make the schedule.
And you have to remember, the players' jobs depend on the results they get.
Such decisions are never made lightly.
Brexit camp could win if economy remains calm until 2017

David Cameron's strategy for renegotiating Britain's position in Europe and keeping it in the EU is getting more and more tangled, even without the election of the brilliant Jeremy “In or out?” Corbyn as Labour leader or the TUC bringing forward strident criticisms of Europe on Tuesday.
Foreigners also have their own characters like Corbyn and Nigel Farages.

An EU diplomat explained this week that – engulfed in similar crises to the one in the EU – not all of them internally provoked - some member states are being fuelled with the UK’s agenda of concessions and treaty changes, which most do not want.
At the annual meeting in Brighton, the TUC decided they did not want it either if it eroded social protection.
We could even call it Dave and George's "selfie" agenda.

The prime minister and chancellor go to summits or bilateral sessions in foreign capitals, they take a picture in front of a famous local monument, with or without the local representative, then they go home and claim they have won allies for reform.
It is only about me.

My European friend, who wants a Britain with an outward-looking perspective under the EU roof - "Don't leave us alone with France," says Berlin - suggests that a number of thickheaded ministers and officials in certain capitals have reached the point where they don't care if Britain stays or goes.

Angela Merkel, the cautious German chancellor, is an ally but has been in power for 10 years and wants to leave before her position is weakened, as happened to Thatcher (11 years), Mitterrand (14) and Kohl (16) who stayed too long.
In 2017, France's president, Francois Hollande, will be reelected or replaced.
And his power is on the wane.
Poland could soon have a right-wing nationalist government, Spain a left-wing one.

It is hard to believe this will help the posing English, whose energy would be better spent trying to stop Scotland leaving the UK - something they do not want either because most of them have similar separatist tendencies.
So, some ministers might even plan to deliberately make unhelpful remarks, in the style of the SNP, in the campaign for Britain’s 2017 referendum, to hasten the Brexit process, my friend suggests.
The renegotiation "was fixed" and "Britain got nothing of value from the renegotiation."

Europeans know from experience just how all-consuming Fleet Street can be and how sceptical the oligarchic press barons can be about the EU, because they did not take part in Tony Benn's 1975 referendum which ratified our 1973 entry by two to one.
You may vaguely remember Boris Johnson, the Euro-opportunist, who became famous in the early 1990s as a Brussels correspondent.
Ed Miliband knew his enemies.
They included a mix of tax-dodging bagmen, foreign phone fraudsters and pseudo non-doms who own most of the big newspapers.

In fact, Tony Blair saw it the same way, but he realized that when you are locked in a cage with an angry gorilla, you have to give him bananas to distract him from the thought of eating you for lunch and again for tea.

Indeed, Miliband was more Blairite than Blair in his opposition to Cameron's referendum idea, given that Blair made a concession on principle with regard to the EU constitution abandoned and buried by French and Dutch voters in 2005, which provided him an exit card.
The press has not forgiven him for that.

But Jeremy Corbyn, who patted me on the back affably on Monday in Westminster – I told him not to waste his time on me – seems in danger of adopting Murdoch's 1980s strategy of boycotting Neil Kinnock, a mistake then and now.
It may take time, but it needs to develop a coherent strategy for cooperation with the media, not with me, but certainly with Andy Marr whose position at the BBC left vacant on Sunday.
Corbyn's official position on Europe is what I would charitably call evolving.
He said he wants to remain in a reformed EU.
Most of those who disagree with the conservative 'anglicism' may agree with this.
That was Hilary 'a Benn, but not a Bennite' Benn on radio and TV this week, as the scout in him struggled not to admit that Corbyn's appointment of John McDonnell as shadow chancellor was a bad idea.
It reminded me of the 1970s when his father fought on TV to be disloyal to his Labour colleagues without going too far and losing his cabinet post.
Hillary's fight was more attractive.
But the fight to 'remain in any situation' - Benn's phrase - does not tally with what McDonnell has said or what JC told colleagues and MPs in a private meeting on Monday night.

No matter what image Corbyn wants to project - and he's certainly got me going - message discipline remains important in the TV age, and especially in the whirl of social media, a hotbed of paranoia and betrayal.
It is right not to give Cameron a free pass in Europe, allowing him to take for granted Labour's support in the referendum campaign, McDonnell said.
Simon Jenkins certainly thinks so.

But McDonnell and Corbyn's basic sophistry on EU membership — in keeping with their anti-capitalist past — is no longer merely an esoteric discussion among left-wing dissidents for whom the narcissism of small differences is a central dogma.
Like his sophistry on NATO - Tom Watson is adamant that JC will not campaign for withdrawal - foreign diplomats will be left to try to understand.
Why should Paris or Berlin waste political capital - and there are suspicious voters there - on concessions to Britain when it might all be for nothing?

The US is already quite disappointed with Britain's poor military performance in Iraq, Libya and Syria, even with a Conservative government cutting costs, as I was reminded at the launch of the British Influence Security Forum on Monday.
Health Experts Criticize UK Public Health England's Decision on E-Cigarettes
According to researchers, a government agency's claims that e-cigarettes are 95 percent less harmful than smoking were the result of a meeting of 12 people, some with ties to the tobacco industry.
The editorial team of the British Medical Journal (BMJ) has joined The Lancet in criticising the evidence used by Public Health England (PHE) in its report on e-cigarettes.
PHE published the “landmark” report last month and described it as a “comprehensive analysis of the evidence.”
But some researchers have questioned the robustness of the data and pointed to links between certain experts and the tobacco industry.
An article published last month in the Lancet medical journal attacked the “extraordinarily flimsy basis” on which PHE had based its main conclusion.
Two other researchers writing in BMJ have questioned the claims and their "solid ground or shifting sand" basis.

Martin McKee, professor of European public health at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, and Simon Capewell, professor of clinical epidemiology at the University of Liverpool, said: “A fundamental principle of public health is that policies should be based on evidence of effectiveness.”
They said they expected PHE's claims that "current estimates suggest e-cigarettes are around 95% less harmful than smoking" to be based on a detailed analysis of the evidence and models.

In fact, a single meeting involving 12 people led to the development of a multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) model which synthesised their views on the negative effects associated with different nicotine-containing products; the results of this meeting were briefly presented in a research paper.

McKee and Capewell said that one of the meeting's sponsors was a company called EuroSwiss Health, whose executive director was said to have received funding from British American Tobacco in the past for conducting an independent study.
He also validated BAT's accreditation in public health in a sustainability report, he said.

They added that one of the 12 participants in the meeting disclosed funding received from an e-cigarette manufacturer, but not the funding reportedly received from tobacco and cigarette company Philip Morris International.
No details were provided on how the panel members were selected but among them are several well-known "leaders" in the e-cigarette industry, some of whom declare funding from the industry.
Other participants in the meeting are not known for their expertise in tobacco control.
The meeting was also attended by the Head of the Tobacco Control Section of PHE.
The review “convincingly whitewashes the lack of robust evidence on the harmful effects of most products on most criteria,” McKee and Capewell said.
However, the PHE report does not mention any of these links or limitations.
McKee and Capewell said PHE's claims that "so far there is no evidence that e-cigarettes are acting as a route into smoking for children or non-smokers" are premature.
Professor Kevin Fenton, director of health and wellbeing at PHE, said the BMJ claims had been addressed previously.
He said: "E-cigarettes are significantly less harmful than smoking."
One in two lifelong smokers dies from the habit.
All the evidence suggests that the health risk from e-cigarettes is low, but we need to continue to study the long-term effects.
PHE has a clear duty to inform the public of what the evidence does and does not say, especially given the high level of public confusion about the relative risks compared to smoking.
Around 80,000 people die each year from a smoking-related illness and the annual cost to the NHS of smoking is £2bn.
By clearly stating the current evidence - that while e-cigarettes are not without risk, they carry only a fraction of the harm of smoking - we are doing our national duty.
Illegal torture equipment - delivered to your door!
Ads Shame U.K. Arms Trade
Watch the film made by Amnesty International against the arms trade.
Terrifying Killer Drones!
Ankle crushers!
Dispersal bombs!
And electric batons that cause excruciating pain without leaving a mark!

The chirpy voiceover and animated graphics leave no doubt that this ad for the world's biggest arms fair is a savage spoof, made by Amnesty International to highlight the UK government's desire to sell arms to repressive regimes through the Defence and Security Equipment International at the ExCeL Centre in London's Docklands.

But a separate campaign has also led to a number of posters in bus and subway stations that need a second look.

In September this year, a host of arms dealers will descend on the DLR and customers are being asked to contribute towards stopping the arms fair.
The 300 posters were made by artists who exhibited their work at the Cruel Designs Museum, in Banksy's Dismaland.

A group called the Special Patrol Group contributed to the distribution in London using “Ad Space Hack Packs,” a £6 pack of Allen keys which they claim “facilitate access to approximately one third of all bus stop ad space on the planet.”
London's transport authority is not amused by this "vandalism" in the form of fliers.
One of the parody announcements produced by Special Patrol Group.

According to Gavin Grindon, curator of Cruel Designs and lecturer at the University of Essex, artists are increasingly asking questions and looking to make political works accessible to audiences outside galleries.
Many artists are turning to collaborating with activists in protest movements, realizing they have to get out into the real world for their art to have an impact on society.
Another poster against the arms trade greets commuters on the underground.

The film made by Amnesty has had over 100,000 views on Facebook in 24 hours and was created by ad agency VCCP who worked pro bono, and the graphic designer and the voice-over artist both worked for free.

VCCP creative director Matt Lever was shocked by the silence surrounding the arms fair - with a blank space in the ExCel calendar - and thought: "Let's give them the campaign they're trying to avoid."
They played with making a more realistic advertisement but “by adding animation and bright colors, it was more striking”.
“They have done a great job helping us raise awareness of the illegal trade in torture equipment at the fair,” said Tom Davies on behalf of Amnesty.
Now it's up to British authorities to take action and ensure that torture equipment is not sold illegally and delivered to the door.
Perhaps the most creative art on the arms fair theme comes from inside ExCeL, where exhibitors offer fantastically euphemistic products.
In a press release, Saab disclosed an order received from the U.S. Army for “AT4CS RS with Shoulder-Supported Launcher.”
It includes "a unique shaped charge that delivers stunning effects behind the armor, inside the target."
Whatever it means, it won't be pleasant.
Eight golden rules for living in a dorm

It's been 11 years since I moved into my dorm, when I was a 19-year-old who still believed in berets and moral relativism, yet it's only now that I remember the forced smiles of those I annoyed and the numerous complaints about others.
Most of what I've learned can be summed up in eight simple rules.
Moving into a dorm can bring on feelings ranging from nervousness to terror.

Chatting is tempting: to tell people where you’re from, if and where you took a gap year, what you think of Corbyn and why “honestly, you don’t care about Marmite because, seriously guys, it’s only yeast extract HAHAHA, find me in my room.”
Take a deep breath.
And help others breathe - ask questions and show interest.
They spark conversation and help you distinguish the people you like from those you wouldn't talk to if the flood came and they were the only ones with boats.
Don't suffocate people.
Dorm rooms often abound with drinking parties, movie nights and social gatherings, but they are also the place where people get dressed and try on their underwear.
Related topics: Don't even think about starting college in a relationship
Introverts get special treatment at university.
Your dorm room should be a refuge, but in many dorms a culture of room-hopping is built on friendship, socialization and lifelong friendships.
All this can be awful for someone who is trying to recharge their batteries.
Nothing in this culture allows you to say, "I like you and I want to stay friends, but I want you to leave so I can recover the energy I have spent interacting with you."
Try to notice when a colleague is overwhelmed by socializing - and try sending a text instead of knocking on the door.
Speaking of knocking on the door: do it.
A guy who lived in my dorm had a policy that if a door wasn't locked, then he was invited to enter.
He's seen enough.
Make friends by cooking.

So as you start university in the Bake Off fever, if you knock on someone's door to introduce yourself and bring a plate of brownies, it seems less weird, less 1950s "Welcome to the neighbourhood, I baked you something, now smile while I ask you personal questions."
Homemade treats are a great way to make friends.
Your roommates will feel obliged to talk and might associate your face with a tasty surprise.
Of course, you have to be a good cook.
The flour, sugar and fat bombs will probably make the others pretend to be asleep when you knock on the door.
Food theft is a common crime in student dormitories.
Obviously if you steal someone's chicken it's theft, but if you take a drop of milk to put in your tea, it's still theft?
Ask the owner.
He will probably tell you to serve it even if it is boiling inside.

If someone steals your things, it's annoying, and I get it — you're still trying to approach the problem more maturely than my dorm mate who dyed her milk with liquid detergent to punish the people who stole it.
He is currently in jail.
Don't make noise that doesn't let others sleep or study.
Not only because it is common sense, but because you literally walk on shards.
A girl on my floor asked her neighbor to turn down the music because it was 3 AM and she had an exam in the morning.
Their reaction was to turn the music up.
When the music finally stopped at 5 a.m., the girl was nice enough to let them sleep for two hours before cranking the music back up to full blast, locking the door and leaving for a three-hour exam.
Wouldn't it be romantic if your future husband/wife moved on the same floor?

On the other hand, wouldn't it be weird if you confused a neighbor with your future husband, you got involved and then broke up and you had to see him every day and maybe even see him take over all your common friends?
Of course, you can't fight the heart – but if a sexy neighbor is definitely not your future husband, at least try to be rational.
The line between a prank and a threat is thinner than it seems in the moment when you realize someone has left their keys in an unlocked room.
A successful prank is funny, but it can sour in a matter of minutes.
Teach a fun and valuable lesson on safety by hiding something - but never mess up someone's room with toothpaste and shampoo.
Lock the door and put the keys in a cup of water that you put in the freezer - but don't glue someone's possessions to the ceiling more than twice.
Violinist David Grimal: There were no world tours in Bach's time.
Beethoven, Brahms, Bartok, Enescu were people who worked, artists and not commercial representatives.

The French violinist David Grimal is one of the great musicians of our times, known not only as a soloist but also as the initiator of a less usual project, quite "strange", as he himself says, Les Dissonances - an orchestra composed of international soloists and talented musicians who perform a symphonic repertoire without a conductor, which makes it at least a curiosity in the classical musical landscape.

Les Dissonances was at the Enescu Festival this year with two shows: one on Sunday with David Grimal, the orchestra's founder, as the soloist, and one on Monday with cellist Xavier Phillips in the lead, with works by Enescu included.
Both shows, held at the Athenaeum stage, showed the public a different way to interpret classical music.
Les Dissonances appeared on the musical scene in 2004 as the only classical music ensemble without a conductor.
The conductor is the most important musician for the musicians.
It is true, on the one hand musicians need education either to become soloists or to become performers in an orchestra - I'm talking about instrumentalists, not composers.
They are trained as "skilled workers".
They themselves have the impression that they need a conductor.
On the other side of the scene, for the public, all the musical fetishism is centered on the conductor.
And so, business, the music industry, makes marketing.
So, we're not talking about music anymore.
"So if you look at this world, you have on the one hand skilled workers, which is stupid, and you have an audience who can't listen but has to look, which is also stupid," David Grimal says.
The violinist says this change in the way he makes music came after "musical disappointments" in his solo career.
I was like a high-level athlete who had to do the same exercise all around the world with different orchestras, to make a lot of money and to bring money to the music industry.
When I was around 30 years old, some 10 years ago, I found this very depressing because I could no longer find creativity and human fraternity in this system.
So I found no sense in continuing on this path.
So I decided to create Les Dissonances.
This was in 2004, and at the time nobody was doing it without a conductor: "The musical world, very conservative, didn't want these kinds of projects."
"How do you imagine doing marketing with a group of musicians in which there is no more ego?" the artist asked.
David Grimal admits that Les Dissonances is a "luxury," saying that none of the musicians in the orchestra depends on the success of this project to live.

In the 10 years of the ensemble's existence, the lack of a conductor has not proven to be an obstacle in the musical act: "Curiously, the more complex the repertoire, the easier it seems, because all the musicians are forced to be present in the opera and not just in their role," Grimal said, adding that in Sunday's performance "there were 74 conductors on stage."

According to Grimal, the Enescu Festival is a "very courageous" one, precisely because it invited Les Dissonances: "An extraordinary festival, where the world's greatest orchestras are playing three times a day, and in the middle of these orchestras, you have invited this odd group".
In a temple of orchestral tradition such as the Enescu Festival, there is room and interest for something different, which breaks barriers.

When talking about Enescu's work, the violinist admits that he feels the Romanian music of the great Romanian composer, so he didn't need a special approach when he introduced Enescu's works in his repertoire.
Grimal writes that Enescu's music is very instinctive, but that happens when we talk about George Enescu and Romanian music, "because there is also a George Enescu who made French music."

Grimal advocates for changing the way classical music education is done, saying that "the profession of musician, as it is organized today, has a whiff of death" and that the "future of music is music itself."
We don't need to go around the world 5 times a year if it doesn't serve any purpose.
In Bach's time there were no world tours.
Beethoven, Brahms, Bartok, Enescu were people who worked, who were artists and not commercial representatives.
For me, organizing concerts, festivals, tours, album launches, all these are wonderful, extraordinary, as long as they are done in the service of music.
If not, we're in a system where creativity suffers, it doesn't have freedom anymore.

To illustrate this phenomenon, David Grimal gave the example of Romanian products before and after accession to the European Union: "In Romania, before you entered the EU, you had good vegetables and meat".
To enter the EU you had to adopt sanitary laws that are not good for vegetables and meat.
Production and agriculture are in the service of supermarkets, as in France.
It's the same with music, it's the same logic.
Les Dissonances make ugly reds, but when you cut them they are real reds.

In an ideal world, the music should come back to the center and the institutions and industries that manage the system should understand that music doesn't need to be sold, it needs to be shared, and that can start with an educational policy.

"If we were to consider - as the Koreans, the Chinese, or the Japanese do - that Western music is one of the most beautiful things in humanity, we would reintroduce its learning in school, we would reintroduce concerts on TV and through this education we would no longer need to sell musical sub-products", Grimal believes.
There are certainly things in classical music education that remain very communist, that's everywhere, it's very militarized.
It depends on this discipline whether we compare a musician with a soldier, or whether we form a musician who will play an instrument, being, above all, a musician.
We are talking about a completely different education, if we want to train a soldier (this education - n.red.) it has to be in one way, if we want to train a musician, it's totally different.
"In your opinion, which is more dangerous, a soldier or a musician?", the French artist asks, smiling.

Grimal explains that for artists, the reward for another way of making music comes from overcoming this "soldier" status, overcoming what "they believe are their limits": "Musicians discover at a certain moment that they are not soldiers, and that is why they come out smiling after the concert".

David Grimal spoke about his musical project and his vision on music and the artist in the "Festival of Ideas," a public discussion organised as part of the George Enescu International Festival by the Aspen Institute Romania.
David Grimal profile

After studying at the Conservatoire National Superieur de Musique in Paris under Regis Pasquier and receiving advice and encouragement from renowned artists such as Schlomo Mintz and Isaac Stern, David Grimal spent a year studying at the Ecole des Science Politiques in Paris before meeting Philippe Hirshhorn, who changed the course of his life.

David Grimal has had an international career as a soloist, regularly performing concerts in the last 20 years on the major classical music stages of the world and with prestigious orchestras such as the Orchestre de Paris, Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France, Russian National Orchestra, Orchestre National de Lyon, Chamber Orchestra of Europe, Berliner Symphoniker, New Japan Philharmonic, Orchestre de l'Opera de Lyon, Mozarteum Orchestra Salzburg, Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra and Sinfonia Varsovia, under conductors such as Christoph Eschenbach, Michel Plasson, Michael Schￃnwandt, Peter Csaba, Heinrich Schiff, Lawrence Foster, Emmanuel Krivine, Mikhail Pletnev, Rafael Fruￌhbeck de Burgos and Peter Eotvos, Andris Nelsons, Christian Arming.

He has been the recipient of works dedicated to him from composers including Marc-Andre Dalbavie, Brice Pauset, Thierry Escaich, Jean-Francois Zygel, Alexander Gasparov, Victor Kissine, Fuminori Tanada, Richard Dubugnon, Ivan Fedele, Philippe Harrowing, Anders Hillborg, Oscar Bianchi, Guillaume Connesson and Frederic Verrieres.
Aside from his solo career, David Grimal has also explored personal projects.
The freedom offered by his collaboration with Les Dissonances allowed him to develop his inner universe by exploring repertoires that are not accessible to solo artists.
Alongside Les Dissonances, he founded "L'Autre Saison", a series of concerts given for and with homeless people at the Saint-Leu church, in the heart of Paris.
Since 2008, David Grimal has been Artist in Residence at the Dijon Opera.
He teaches violin at the Musikhochschule in Saarbrücken, Germany.
He also gives master classes and was a member of the jury of the International Long-Thibaud Competition in Paris in 2010.
He received the Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres from the French Minister of Culture in 2008.
David Grimal plays a Stradivarius, "ex Roederer" from 1710, as well as "Don Quijote", a violin designed for him by the French luthier Jacques Fustier.
David Grimal was present on Sunday in this year's George Enescu International Festival with the Les Dissonances Orchestra, with a program of Debussy, Enescu and Beethoven.
Les Dissonances took the stage again on Monday, this time with cellist Xavier Phillips in the spotlight, and the program comprised Schnittke, Enescu and Brahms.
Cinema City is looking for "Big Little Voices"
Cinema City launches the coolest challenge for kids: dubbing two characters from the super-production "Snow Queen 3D"
Do you have a super-talented and spontaneous child who likes movies?
Give him the chance to become a star.

In September, as part of its latest campaign for enthusiastic, ambitious children between the ages of 8 to 16, who want to become future stars, Cinema City is looking for "Little Big Voices," offering them the extraordinary opportunity to dub two characters from a famous animated film.

While in the classic cartoons the emphasis was put on the fact that the actor's voice sounded similar to the animated character, in the last period, when creating the story, the people who are supposed to interpret the voices are also taken into consideration, and they are usually well-known actors.
Cinema City Romania, however, wants to discover new voices and that is why we are launching an unprecedented campaign.
We want to find the right voice and challenge parents to enter their children in our competition.
They will have a special experience, because the characters are nice and the lines are funny.
"The children will have fun and will have a real chance to be part of an acting team," said Ioana Ionescu, Marketing Manager of Cinema City Romania.

In the first stage of the competition, from September 11 to September 30, Cinema City will hold a pre-selection, after which 10 children (five girls and five boys) will be chosen, who will be given the opportunity to audition in a recording studio alongside professionals.
All parents have to do is access micilevocimari.cinema-city.ro, where they can register their child for the contest and prepare them for the voice test.
Next, they must select one of the four movies available on the platform, download the texts that the child will read and then the child will record his or her own dubbing version.

Four films about friendship, fairy-tale heroes, magic and hope can choose contestants for the support test: "Pene Galbene 3D", "Mune - Guardian of the Moon 3D", "Blinky Bill: Koala cel poznaș 3D" and "Albinuța Maya 3D".

FedEx Earnings Mixed, Cuts Fiscal 2016 Forecast

FedEx Corp. reported disappointing results for its latest quarter, as the shipping giant cut its profit outlook for the year because of weak demand for shipping services and higher costs for its ground delivery business.
The company also said it plans to hire around 55,000 seasonal workers for the holiday season.
Last year, FedEx announced it would hire 50,000 seasonal workers for the holidays.
Shares of the company fell about 2.5 percent in pre-market trading, 45 minutes before the opening bell Wednesday.
FedEx Corp. said it expects to earn between $10.40 and $10.90 a share for its fiscal year ending in May 2014, 20 cents less than a prior estimate.
Analysts had forecast $10.84, according to a survey by FactSet.

The downward estimate comes despite a 4.9 percent average price increase that took effect Jan. 4 and higher surcharges for ground delivery of large or heavy packages that will take effect in November.
The company said it still expects earnings to grow from the previous year, due to cost cuts, higher revenues and the development of online trading.
President and CEO Fred Smith said “the company is facing a much weaker economic environment than we previously anticipated, particularly in global production and trade.”
The hiring plans were announced a day after UPS rival FedEx said it plans to hire 90,000-95,000 seasonal workers, about the same number it hired last year.
In the quarter ended August 31, FedEx earned $692 million, up 6% from a year earlier.
Earnings per share were $2.42, short of the average estimate of $2.44 per share by 12 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.
Profit rose 5 percent to $12.3 billion.
Six analysts participating in the Zacks survey had expected $12.23 billion.
FedEx has been hit in recent years by a decline in international priority shipping, which has led to flat revenue at its Express unit.
But a boom in online shopping boosted FedEx Ground's results.
In the last quarter, ground division revenue increased 29% but operating income was virtually flat due to higher costs for large packages and self-insurance.
The express unit recorded an increase in revenues due to higher base rates, while revenue at the freight division fell due to rising costs.
In pre-market trading, about an hour before the opening bell, FedEx shares fell $3.85, or 2.5%, to $150.15.
They were down 11% on the year and 17% from their record high on June 11.

In the most anticipated meeting in years, Federal Reserve policymakers will spend two days this week around a 27-foot Honduran mahogany table to decide whether it is time to raise a key interest rate for the first time in nearly a decade.
Above them, at one end of the central bank's board room, will loom a mural painting of the United States.
The map is meant to remind Janet L. Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, and her colleagues that they must put the nation’s economic interests above all else.
The Federal Reserve has a dual mandate from Congress: to maximize employment in the United States and to maintain price stability.
But since the Great Recession, Fed leaders have confirmed there is a third, unwritten mandate: financial stability.

And that third factor could be the X-factor in a decision too difficult to call, to be announced Tuesday, that will determine whether the U.S. economy is ready to be weaned off the unprecedented stimulus of near-zero short-term interest rates that have been in place since late 2008.

While most data point to a strong growth economy, recent turmoil in global financial markets could spook Fed officials already wary of adding volatility by raising the federal funds rate - even by a quarter of a percentage point.
"Clearly the labor market and inflation will be the first and foremost things they'll be looking at," said Lindsey M. Piegza, chief economist at brokerage firm Stifel Nicolaus & Co.
"But I think if they were looking for an excuse to not raise rates, the rising uncertainty in global markets is enough to give them an excuse to wait," she said.
There is no consensus about what Fed will do, and that itself is causing instability in the financial markets.
About half of the economists surveyed by Bloomberg recently expected a rate hike this week.
But financial markets are expecting the Fed to wait, with one key index showing only a 30% probability of a hike.
That would indicate a stock market slide if the Fed raises rates, unless policymakers soften the blow by promising it would be a long time before the next increase.
On Tuesday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 228.89 points, or 1.4%, to 16,599.85.
The surge was fueled by expectations that Fed policymakers will keep interest rates steady this week, said John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Capital Markets Research Group.
"It would be surprising if the Fed raised rates at this moment," Lonski said.
If Fed policymakers do this, “they should act deeply in their policies to avoid panic in financial markets.”
Other experts said an interest rate hike would calm financial markets because it would remove uncertainty about when the Fed will act.

Just a month ago, the Fed seemed on track to raise rates by 0.25% this month, the first small step toward a slow tightening of monetary conditions that would confirm the strength of the U.S. recovery.
Yellen said in the spring and early summer that she expected a rate hike this year despite objections from liberals that more economic progress was needed.
While job creation slowed in August, the labor market has been strong this year.
The unemployment rate fell to 5.1 percent last month, the lowest in more than seven years and close to the level the Fed considers full employment.
Wages showed signs of growth.
And while inflation continued to undershoot the central bank's annual target, Fed policymakers said a key reason was the temporary effect of sharply falling oil prices.
“The economy can handle higher rates and needs them, given the tightness in the labor market,” said Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics.
But global financial markets went into a tailspin at the end of last month after China devalued its currency.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 16% from its May record high as investors worried that a slowing Chinese economy would drag down global growth.
The market has pulled back somewhat this month, with the Dow index now about 10 percent below its May peak.
For Fed policymakers, the market turmoil adds to the complex calculus of when to raise rates.

"Without what happened in the financial markets and the news about the weakening of the Chinese economy in the last few weeks, they would be firmer inside the meeting," said Stephen D. Oliner, an experienced researcher at the UCLA Ziman Center for Real Estate and former Fed official.
Now, he predicts they will wait at least a month to better manage the effects.
"There is a lot of uncertainty about what the impact on the U.S. economy will be and we almost have no data to go on after the events in China," Oliner said.
Global economic well-being isn't one of the Fed's major concerns, so it shouldn't be considered when making decisions.
But in reality, the Fed has become the world's monetary authority.
In recent years, the central bank's influence has been huge.
A mere hint in 2013 by then-Fed Chairman Ben S. Bernanke that the Fed might "taper" its monetary expansion triggered a global market earthquake.

In a world where markets and economies are increasingly intertwined, it is to be expected that Fed officials not only monitor developments in other areas, but also consult with other central banks and experts to better interpret the global economy.
The Fed's decision-making process is "more art than science," said Zachary Karabell, head of global strategy at wealth manager Envestnet Inc.

Jeffrey Lacker, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Va., said this month that the Fed has a “history of overreacting to changes in financial markets that don't seem to have much to do with the underlying economy.”
Lacker, a voting member of the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets interest-rate policy, cited the Fed's actions in 1998-99.
A financial crisis in Asia prompted the Fed to cut the benchmark rate by 0.75 percentage point in three meetings, "despite the limited implications for U.S. developments," Lacker said.
A year later, Fed officials reversed those cuts.

The Fed should put financial stability at the top of its agenda only in case of a major crisis, such as the 2008 market quake, said Adam S. Posen, a former member of the Bank of England's rate-setting committee.
The recent turmoil is nowhere near that level, he said.
"We certainly don't want to get into a situation where we fear a rise in interest rates because the markets are upset," said Posen, president of the Peterson Institute for International Economics.
The Federal Reserve Act still has a dual mandate and doesn't mention financial stability and, until something changes in that regard, I don't think they should take any premature action.
Looking for an amazing Thai market?
Try LAX-C in Chinatown.
Yes, Chinatown
The open-air market that opened in 1997 belongs to LAX-C Inc.
Often called the Thai Costco, LAX-C is a Thai wholesale market that also sells to the public.
Yes, it's in Chinatown and not in Thai Town.
The market/depot is a full-service store offering an amazing range of fresh, frozen and dried products, popular Thai and Asian snacks and kitchenware, furniture, religious and holiday decorations.
There is also an auto parts district if you need to buy some motor oil.
The store is huge and it takes at least an hour to walk through all the aisles.
If you get hungry from all that shopping, eat at LAX-C BBQ Express.
The store's interior food court (good, reasonably priced) is close to home, and offers more options for take-out meals.
What's in stock: Need something - anything - Thai?
You'll probably find it at LAX-C.
The products are reasonably priced and some items are sold wholesale.
Fresh produce includes herbs, fruits and other Asian and Thai products.
The meat section is huge, as is the fish section - the staff serving will clean and filet the fish and even fry it for you if you wish.

A large part of the store is dedicated to the huge freezer section, where you will find frozen curry leaves, watermelon and ginger, whole ducks, fish, blood and ox balls, pork carcasses, fishballs, traditional sausages, semi-prepared ingredients and many more.
Who buys there: Restaurant owners and chefs, also families and individuals.
The wide aisles can accommodate both shopping carts and forklifts.
Discovery: Fresh Durian fruits just next to the residential area.
Where it is: The store is located in an industrial area of Los Angeles, on the outskirts of Chinatown and Downtown - just a few blocks from Philippe The Original.
Parking: LAX-C has its own shared parking area with other stores and restaurants.
Although the store is crowded, it is usually easy to find a parking space.

4 Killed as Nepal Police Fire Rubber Bullets at Protesters

Four people, including a 4-year-old boy, were killed in southern Nepal after police fired rubber bullets at a crowd demonstrating against the country's proposed new constitution, an official said Wednesday.
The violence occurred Tuesday night in the Rupandehi district, about 280 kilometers west of the capital, Kathmandu.
Bishnu Prasad Dhakal, the district police chief, said more than 1,000 protesters gathered in front of a police station and some of them threw stones and Molotov cocktails.
Mr. Dhakal said police used tear gas and fired warning shots before resorting to rubber bullets.
He said 20 police officers and five civilians were injured.
It was not immediately clear why the rubber bullets, which are known to be lethal but are usually used as a less-lethal alternative, caused so many deaths.

The clash was the latest in weeks of violent protests in southern Nepal, where members of the Madhesi ethnic group say the new provinces created under the new constitution would dilute their political influence.
Protests have also been held in western Nepal, where the Tharu ethnic group is demanding its own state.
At least 40 people, including 11 police officers, were killed in the violent clashes that erupted on August 10.

when four major political parties signed an agreement to divide the country into provinces - a major step toward a new constitution but an extremely controversial issue in Nepal, a country that has been ruled centrally for hundreds of years.
The process to draft a new constitution was launched in 2008, but lawmakers accelerated the process after the devastating earthquake that killed thousands in April.
Lawmakers in Kathmandu this week voted on the draft constitution's provisions and officials said the new charter could be adopted Sunday.

Romania does not agree and will not implement anti-democratic measures, guard dogs, barbed-wire fences or police with weapons.

"The prime minister also said that all the data and details of the refugee crisis will be discussed and established at the CSAT meeting on Thursday," the prime minister concluded.
NHC says 60% chance of cyclone south of Cape Verde Islands

Weight-Loss Surgery May Help Some Diabetics With Mild Obesity
The benefits of weight-loss surgery for people with mild obesity and type 2 diabetes may be maintained for at least five years, according to a new study.
It is too early to say whether diabetics with mild obesity live longer after weight-loss surgery than those who follow non-surgical treatments.
"It takes a long time to centralize the data on mortality," said Dr. Robin Blackstone, a bariatric surgeon who wrote an editorial about the new study in JAMA Surgery.
Weight-loss surgeries, also known as bariatric surgery, use various methods to shrink the stomach.
They reduce the feeling of hunger and limit the body's ability to absorb food.

Over the years, bariatric surgery has been shown to be effective in treating type 2 diabetes, but most studies have been conducted in people with morbid obesity, with a body mass index (BMI) of 35 or higher.
BMI, a measure of weight in relation to height, is considered normal in the range of 18.5 to 24.9.
A BMI of at least 25 indicates a person is overweight and people with a BMI over 30 are considered obese.
You can calculate your BMI at: 1.usa.gov/1D0ZqDv.

For the new study, researchers from Min-Sheng General Hospital in Taiwan used data collected after 2007 from a trial comparing two types of bariatric surgery - gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy - for treating type 2 diabetes in people with mild obesity.
The average BMI of people who had surgery dropped from 31 to 24.5 by the end of the fifth year of the study.
Meanwhile, the IMC of people who received non-surgical treatment for diabetes remained almost the same, at 29.
Of those who had surgery, diabetes was completely cured in 36 percent and partially in 28 percent.
In the medically treated group, by comparison, diabetes was completely cured in just 1 percent and partially cured in only 2 percent of subjects.
In addition, blood pressure, triglycerides and "bad" LDL cholesterol "were generally better in the surgical group," the authors concluded.
Researchers also measured blood levels of hemoglobin A1c, which reflects average blood sugar levels over time.
Researchers write that the optimal level of hemoglobin A1c is below 7%.
After surgery, the average hemoglobin A1c level dropped from about 9 percent to about 6 percent.
But in the group treated with medical methods, it remained at about 8%.
But this improved "glycemic control" - reflected by improved hemoglobin A1c levels - did not reduce the five-year mortality rate, lead researcher Dr. Chih-Cheng Hsu and colleagues found.
The research team also compared the average outcomes associated with the two types of surgical intervention.

At 5 years, compared with the sleeve gastrectomy group, the bypass group had lost more weight (18.7 vs 14.2 kg), had greater reductions in BMI (7.4 vs 5.1) and hemoglobin A1c (3.1% vs 2.1%), and had a higher probability of complete remission of diabetes (46.9% vs 16.7%).

While the new study does not show a survival or surgery benefit at five years, there is evidence from a study of obese people in Sweden that surgery extends life, Blackstone, of the University of Arizona College of Medicine - Phoenix, said.
In the Swedish study, obese people who had bariatric surgery had about a 29 percent lower risk of dying after 15 years compared to a group that tried more conventional methods.

Although the new study did not show a benefit in survival for patients who had surgery, Blackstone said it is an encouraging finding for people with a BMI under 35 who are interested in the procedure.
"This is the point where this work is critical, because it says that this surgical intervention is safe in this lower BMI group," without increasing the risk of death or kidney disease, she says.
Blackstone added that patients and their doctors should start taking weight seriously when a patient's BMI reaches 27 to 30.
“I think we wait too long to encourage people to take this seriously,” she said.
I think that once they had accumulated these genetic changes that had short-circuited their bodies and made them prone to obesity and diabetes, it was very hard to get back to normal.
“It is impossible for everyone to come to Europe” - Dalai Lama - RT news
Europe cannot take all refugees, the Dalai Lama said, adding that the real solution to the current refugee crisis lies in the Middle East.
The Tibetan Buddhist leader has issued an appeal for an end to violence in the home countries of refugees.

The Dalai Lama spoke about the current refugee crisis in a speech at the opening of the Dalai Lama Centre for Compassion in Oxford dedicated to the study of ethics, at the start of his 10-day visit to Britain.
He said that in the current situation, the interests of humanity should prevail over the interests of each nation and even each continent.
He also stressed that, while admirable, the response of western European countries to the refugee crisis is inadequate to the situation.
"It is impossible for everyone to come to Europe," he said in his speech.
While the Dalai Lama praised Germany and Austria's efforts to deal with the crisis, he stressed that it is only a temporary solution.
"It's great to care for a few thousand refugees, but we also need to focus on a long-term solution to bring true peace and development, especially through education, to Muslim countries," he said.
Ultimately, we need to think about ways to reduce crime in their countries.
We need to reduce the use of force.
"Force has never solved these problems," he added.

On the issue of violence, the Dalai Lama also commented on George Bush's actions after the 9/11 terrorist attacks, saying that the United States' violent response triggered an uncontrollable chain of events.
After the events of September 11, I sent my condolences in a letter to President Bush and told him to solve this problem without resorting to violence.
"I know his motivation was strong, but he used force and generated unexpected consequences," the Dalai Lama said.
Four-fold rise in number of children ingesting hand sanitiser in last 4 years

According to the Georgia Poison Center, poison control centers in the U.S. have reported a nearly 400 percent increase since 2010 in the number of children under 12 who have swallowed hand sanitizers with a high alcohol content.
According to Dr. Gaylord Lopez, director of the Georgia Poison Center, cases of hand sanitizer ingestion in children under 12 reported to poison centers rose from 3,266 in 2010 to 16,117 in 2014.
"Children have more access to these products and, unfortunately, a percentage of them end up in the emergency room," Lopez told CNN.
Lopez said some children drink detergent intentionally while others do so to impress their friends or to respond to challenges on social media.
YouTube videos show teenagers drinking detergent to create cheap drinks.
It appears the teens mixed the detergent with mouthwash containing alcohol to make a stronger drink.
Young children may be attracted by the attractive smell of detergent.
“A child doesn't think that they're hurting someone,” Lopez said.
Many of the most attractive types are the perfumed ones.
Strawberry, grape and orange-scented hand sanitizers are the most attractive to children.
Hand sanitizer contains about 45-95% alcohol.
Just a few sips can cause alcohol poisoning, especially in young children.
"It's very concentrated alcohol," Dr. Stephen Thornton, medical director for the Poison Control Center at the University of Kansas Hospital, told Kansas City's Fox 4.
So we don't leave a glass of whiskey on the table, but people leave these hand sanitizers in accessible places and if children get to them, this is a quick way to consume a lot of alcohol.
Nhaijah Russell, a six-year-old girl who recently ingested the equivalent of four squirts of strawberry-scented hand sanitizer at school, was rushed to the emergency room for treatment.

She had a blood alcohol level of .179, twice the legal limit at which an adult is considered under the influence of alcohol, according to Dr. Chris Ritchey, an emergency room physician who treated her at Gwinnett Medical Center outside Atlanta.
Nhaijah was vomiting and unable to walk when she arrived at the emergency room.
Doctors monitored her overnight at a separate children's hospital to identify signs of brain injury, because the girl fell and hit her head because of the alcohol, Ritchey said.
"It was scary," Nhaijah's mother, Ortoria Scott, told CNN.
It could have been fatal.
Lopez recommended parents and teachers use alcohol-free wet wipes or tissues and keep hand sanitizer out of children's reach.
In addition to alcohol poisoning, some detergents have been linked to deaths.
In 2013, two women in Ontario died after ingesting hand sanitizer that contained an undisclosed toxic ingredient.
Health authorities suspected the product contained methanol, a deadly substance, instead of ethyl alcohol, listed as the active ingredient.
In January, three fourth-graders in northern New York plotted to poison their “mean” teacher by “putting antibacterial products in the classroom,” according to a police report.

Deila promises to change the situation.

Scottish unemployment rate unchanged as UK rate rises
Scottish unemployment rate remains unchanged at 164,000 in the May-July period, while the number of unemployed people in the UK as a whole rose by 10,000 to 1.82 million in the same period.
Scotland's unemployment rate of 5.9% was higher than the UK rate of 5.5%, according to figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS).

Why I Witnessed an Execution in Oklahoma
Today, barring a last-minute legal intervention, I will watch a man be sentenced to death.
If it happens, and I hope it doesn't, I will stand in the witness room at the Oklahoma State Penitentiary and watch Richard Glossip be executed by lethal injection.
He asked me to be one of the four official witnesses to his death.
The invitation came first in January through his best friend, and although I was shocked, I accepted.
As the day gets nearer, the idea scares me.
So, why should I do it?
I agreed because I thought it was a good way to tell the whole story of the death penalty.
It would provide a unique perspective.
It is true that journalists can witness executions in America and, because requests usually exceed the number of available spots, a macabre lottery is held to decide who will be chosen.
Oklahoma has cut the number of press seats from 12 to five.
The elected ones will watch the execution with impartiality.
I can't do that.
I would stand beside Richard Glossip's closest friends, plus I have developed my own bond with him over months of phone conversations and a two-and-a-half-hour visit.
I like the guy.
We often laugh a lot when we talk.
Prison authorities say I can't be both a witness and a journalist, so I won't be allowed to have a notebook and pen to record what I see.
I'll have to try to remember all the details.
An Oklahoma journalist accused me on Twitter of compromising my impartiality.
Here is the lesson.
Tell the prisoner's story the way he wants it told, get access.
I complained to her.
He acknowledged that he “could have worded it better” but he still believes they are wrong.
Richard Glossip did not agree with some of the things I said and wrote.
He doesn't tell me what to write and I wouldn't do it even if he asked me.
I told him he could remove me from the list of witnesses any time.
But he wants an international report that writes about the topic.
He believes that if he dies, the publicity will help the anti-death penalty movement.
Kim Bellware, a reporter for the Huffington Post, will be joining me.
If you want to find out more about the case, listen to the series of multimedia files I've made.
I will not go into all the details here.
I can't say with certainty that Richard Glossip is innocent.
His actions after the murder of Barry Van Treese make him guilty of complicity.
But I think it is very likely he is not guilty of the crime.
I firmly believe that there was not enough evidence to justify the death penalty.
I think his execution is wrong.
And I will watch him die from this perspective.
I can't claim to be totally objective.
For that, you can read articles written by other reporters.
From me you will learn how it is to watch a man I like die uselessly.
Peter Moody claims stewards tried to spy on him and threatens to withdraw from races
Peter Moody has claimed Racing Victoria stewards tried to plant a spy at his stables last year and threatened to quit racing immediately.

Moody said he had always tried to do his best for the racing industry and was in a difficult position with Lidari's positive cobalt test, for which he had no explanation.
For 18 months, he swallowed his words regarding the spying allegations and didn't want to look “like the fox who couldn't reach the grapes”.
"I was not going to say anything about it, and I kept quiet for a long time, but sometimes you get to a level of frustration that it all just bursts out," Moody said.
It is known to have continued.
Sometimes you react and you have to face the consequences, and I'll have to live with what I said.
Tonight I will go home and sleep peacefully.
I want to go with my head up and I want the owners I work with to see that I'm trying to give them the best.
If they start believing that, I have to quit my job as a trainer.
At that time I'll have to think about what to do with my certification.
Moody had dropped a bombshell earlier in an interview with racing.com in which he said the integrity department had tried to spy on his stables.

Of course he considers me a cheat.
If that is the case, then they should all resign because they were incompetent in trying to catch me.
Robert Roulston, the former president of RVL, David Moodie, the current president of RVL and Bernard Saundry, the current CEO of RVL knew then and they know now.
Should I believe it is something personal?
Is it necessary for RVL to start having a backbone and hold people outside the trainers accountable for what happens in the industry?
Do I have a bad influence on the industry?
Is my influence on the industry that bad?
Maybe that's how others see it.
I may have to have my license taken away and be thrown out and I have no doubt that the statements I'm making now would prompt them to think about that.
I have reached a point where I don't care anymore and that saddens me.
I am very sad.
I will put pressure on and force him to take a decision.
My family supports me and I can leave.
The trainer's frustration has grown amid the extended investigation into a cobalt test involving Lidari and his elimination prompted him to say he could "put his licence on the table".

Breaks the racing rules.
"I have to assume full responsibility for this," he said.
One of my employees accidentally put mud on his foot.
It could have happened last night.
It could have happened yesterday, and it did.
It happened on race day.
Moody could be disqualified for three months for the treatment on the day of the race which was the application of a poultice, for which stewards have opened an inquiry.
It's a joke.
The people who make these rules know nothing about horses.
"We all understand the need for rules, but it has gone too far," Moody said.

Melbourne Storm coach Craig Bellamy hits back at wrestling accusations.
Melbourne Storm coach Craig Bellamy has dismissed criticism of his team's wrestling tactics as “twisted” claims by the NRL's two top teams.
Sydney Roosters coach Trent Robinson has accused referees of allowing Melbourne Storm players to "bash" his side during their fiery qualifying final victory on Friday night.

Brisbane Broncos coach Wayne Bennett made a glancing reference to the Storm after his team's qualifying final defeat of North Queensland Cowboys on Saturday night, calling the match a "demonstration" of rugby league and saying the two Queensland teams were not very good at wrestling.
Bellamy defended his side's tackling tactics and said his players were simply concentrating on "contact" when they tackled.
Bellamy says he has gained confidence after two senior coaches criticised his team, which means they were worried Storm will beat them.
"And it's not just us - I didn't hear Trent Robinson complaining about the wrestling when they beat us 24-2," Bellamy said on Wednesday.

I can guarantee you that we haven't changed anything all year in our defensive systems and techniques, except that the last six weeks we have really emphasized tackling and that has changed the situation.
Trent has been in the job for three years and he obviously has a great team so he's probably not used to losing and it was a shock to him.
We love how it always happens this time of year.
Bellamy contradicted Bennett's idea to "liven up football", reminding his mentor that Bennett's St George-Illawarra Dragons won the 2010 premiership by playing "boring" football.
Wayne talks about exciting football.
He compared Saturday's game with our game on Friday night and he spoke about how exciting the game was,” Bellamy said.
I remember in 2010 St George received a lot of criticism for being a boring team and Wayne said he didn't give a damn.
But now he has a team that can play what we would call exciting football, especially due to the young, fast midfielders.
That's the kind of game you want to play when you have those kind of players.
He made that argument in 2010, now he wants everyone to adopt his style of play - not every team has two halves like Anthony Milford and Ben Hunt to be able to play like that.
It gives me more confidence because they say these things because they are somewhat worried about the match against us.

The Broncos game was probably a good game, I haven't seen it yet, what was the score? 16-12?
Our match ended 20-18, there were two more tries in our game, does that mean it was a thrilling game?
Or is exciting to take breaks and not to score?
For me, there are plans.
If they talk about us, it means that at some point we might meet them.

Stevan Hogg used girls' phones to lure pedophiles into sending images
A paedophile used an 11-year-old girl's phone to request pictures of abused children.
Stevan Hogg took the girl's phone while she was asleep and then logged into an online messaging service where another user sent him a series of indecent images of children.
The girl later woke up and noticed her phone was missing and found it in Hogg's hand while he was sleeping.
He looked through his phone and found the disturbing messages and immediately alerted his mother.
After arriving, police saw the five photos then checked computers found at the address and found “worrying” internet searches using terms to find indecent images of children.
Hogg claimed he did it to "lure pedophiles" on the Internet before "pretending to be a cop" to scare them.
Prosecutor Eilidh Robertson told Dundee Sheriff Court: "He said it was an addiction - that he was addicted to frightening people.
He admitted to the computer searches but said he did so because he wanted to pretend to be a police officer to scare pedophiles.
He was questioned about the conversations he had with the unknown person who sent him the images, and about the fact that he asked the person to send him more pictures.
He said he did it to entice.
He said he doesn't think clearly when he drinks and that he wants to see images of rape and murder.
Mr Robertson said: "When the girl found the messages on the phone, she called her mum and was shaking and crying.
The girl saw the indecent images on the phone and the accused was confronted.
The girl was interviewed and told investigators that the defendant used his computer and Playstation to talk to girls who appeared much younger than him.

Last year, on June 14, Hogg, 23, of Ward Road, Dundee, pleaded guilty to charges of making or taking indecent photographs of children, and breaching the conditions of his bail on January 25 this year and failing to appear in court on March 24 of this year.
Defence lawyer Gregor Simpson argued that Hogg should not be placed on the sex offenders register as the offence “did not involve a significant sexual aspect”.
Judge Alistair Carmichael postponed the sentencing until October, for social reports.
Hogg was released on bail in this case but remains in custody pending hearings on other cases.
He was placed on the sex offenders register before being sentenced.

Hewlett-Packard to Cut 30,000 Jobs
Hewlett-Packard is expected to make between 25,000 and 30,000 job cuts as part of the company's restructuring and cost-cutting efforts in the services sector.
This year, HP will split into two publicly traded companies, separating its personal computer and printer business from its fast-growing corporate hardware and services operations.
The layoffs will cost about $2.7 billion in the fourth quarter, the company said.

"These restructuring actions will drive a more competitive and sustainable cost structure for the new Hewlett Packard Enterprise," Meg Whitman, HP's president and chief executive officer, who will lead the enterprise unit after the split, said in a statement.
"Hewlett Packard Enterprise will be smaller and more focused than HP today with a broad portfolio of businesses that will provide the foundation for the new style of IT," Whitman said.
Operating as a separate company, we are better positioned than ever to meet the growing needs of our global customers.
According to a statement from the company, Hewlett Packard Enterprise will have annual revenues of more than $50 billion, and will "focus on providing integrated solutions to enterprises."

A company founded in 1930 by Stanford University graduates Bill Hewlett and Dave Packard, which produced electrical equipment and whose garage in Palo Alto was called "the cradle of Silicon Valley" is being split.
HP has undergone a massive restructuring to adapt to the shift from traditional computers to mobile devices.

The move by HP, the world's second-largest personal computer maker and one of the largest technology companies in the United States, is the most recent in a string of such moves, based on the idea that companies that focus better in one direction perform better.
FriendsFest: the comedy show that taught us important lessons about male friendship
The lack of such characters in TV shows is glaring, given that the need for men to open up is now more desperate than ever, with suicide rates among young men hitting a 15-year high.
In 2013, suicide was the leading cause of death among men aged 20-45 in Britain, and remains three times more common among men than women.

In an attempt to address the issue, the Campaign Against Living Miserably (CALM) has designated 2015 as the Year of the Man, aiming to challenge the culture that prevents men from asking for help when they need it.
Friendship is at the center of the struggle to achieve this challenge.

A recent study of more than 2,000 high school students who showed signs of depression found that if the patient was surrounded by enough friends "with a healthy mood", their chances of recovery doubled.
Similarly, for people who are not depressed, a circle of mentally healthy friends halves the risk of mental disorders.
Of course, for friendship to work, it must be accessible in the first place.
In this era of social media-driven communications, where style is prioritized over substance, the immediacy of the response often takes precedence over contact with meaning.
Our digital lives have doubled the need to create the appearance of a strong, fun and successful personality, even if in reality isolation is what dominates.

This superficial success is dominated by what psychologists call extrinsic values; money, image, social status, all at the cost of intrinsic values - our inner desire for personal development and friendship - which more deeply affect our mental health.
The billionaire inventor of a video game has recently explained that money does not buy happiness.
The beauty of Friends was that it focused on this idea.
The characters were not defined by their jobs, but by their personalities, which they showed by interacting as friends.

The humor in Joey and Chandler's frequent hugs, the moments they watch football in their comfortable chairs, and Ross's passion for Rachel stems from the fact that men can identify with this situation, even though they often shy away from fully exploring their feelings.
As one social worker explained to me: ...“My role of listening to suicidal and depressed people showed me how even the smallest interactions with friends can make a difference.”
Often the people who contact us don't feel able to talk to their friends.
The old adage to tough it out is strong, as is the perception that you are weak if you talk openly about problems.
Friends is one of the shows that comes to mind when I try to offer more long-term psychological coping mechanisms.
The series highlighted the small moments of friendship between men.
As helpful as external, objective intervention over the phone can be, the long-term support comes from family and close friends
So if you're attending Comedy Central's FriendsFest this weekend, with full recreations of the filming sets to celebrate the event, why not invite your friends out for a coffee in Central Perk.
Or, even better, if you see someone alone in Starbucks, smile and say hello.
You never know what difference your friendship might make.
Friends is being aired by Comedy Central from start to finish - all 236 episodes - to mark #FriendsFest
Di Maria scores, helps PSG ease past Malmo
Angel Di Maria celebrates with Blaise Matuidi and Edinson Cavani after scoring against Malmo.
Angel Di Maria scored on his Champions League debut on Tuesday to help Paris Saint-Germain beat Swedish side Malmo.
Now here's the report on the game and reaction to the match.
Angel Di Maria and Edinson Cavani did the job as Paris Saint-Germain began their Champions League campaign with a comfortable 2-0 win over Malmo at the Parc des Princes on Tuesday.

Di Maria scored in less than four minutes of his Champions League debut for PSG, putting the French champions ahead despite missing a string of chances before Cavani sealed the win in the 61st minute.

Drawn in Group A along with Real Madrid and Shakhtar Donetsk, PSG needed a strong start against the Swedish champions as the French side's goal is not just to qualify for the knockout rounds but also to improve on their quarterfinal exits in each of the last three tournaments.

But although they took the points, Laurent Blanc's side were far from a perfect picture, with Zlatan Ibrahimovic wasting a chance before being replaced by the team from his home town and the club where he started his glittering career in 1999.

"It's not easy to win at home or away in the Champions League, so winning 2-0 creates problems for our opponents and establishes a comfortable difference from the next-placed teams, even if there are still aspects that we have to work on over the course of the season," Blanc said.
It is a good sign.
We wanted to win and we did it, although I'm sorry we didn't manage to score one or two more goals.
Ibrahimovic returned from injury with one of three changes to the Paris team, with a 2-2 draw at home to Bordeaux in Ligue 1 at the weekend, but Di Maria grabbed the limelight in the fourth minute.

When the Argentina forward was transferred from Manchester United last month he was billed as the man to take PSG to the next level in Europe and he proved it when he burst on to Marco Verratti's pass behind the Malmo defence before unleashing an incredible shot over Johan Wiland into the top-right corner.
But if anyone expected PSG to win with a snap of their fingers, they were disappointed.
Malmo, who beat Celtic in the play-offs to reach this stage and lined up with nine players with international experience and a five-man defence and two holding midfielders, were a tough opponent.
But their attack was not impressive, with the exception of Nikola Djurdjic's shot that went past Kevin Trapp in the 34th minute.

Instead, PSG players slowed the pace several times, giving a few unnecessary passes and failing to finish the attacks, even Ibrahimovic who missed no less than five attempts only in the first half and was then replaced by Cavani right after the game resumed.
Ibrahimovic proved more adept at setting up his teammates, though, his pass to Di Maria was deflected by Wiland into the net in the 52nd minute.
The second goal came in the end after an hour of the game, thanks to Cavani, the Uruguayan who scored the sixth goal of the season, after Ibrahimovic passed from Maxwell's cross.

That goal ended Malmo's hope of mounting a comeback, and only a superb save from Wiland from long range to deny David Luiz kept the score down before substitute Ezequiel Lavezzi had a goal ruled out in added time.
Malmo coach Age Hareide said afterwards that PSG were a class apart and that "The last Champions League game I played was in December last year."
Since then, I have only played in the Swedish league, which is not to the same level.
Qualifications are not enough.
Hats off to PSG.
They played a great game.
Glencore raises $2.5 billion from share sale
Swiss mining giant Glencore, hit by falling commodity prices, has raised $2.5 billion from a share sale as part of a broad plan to slash its massive debt.
Glencore, listed on the London Stock Exchange, said it sold new shares worth $2.6 billion to help pay down the debt.
Following a loss of 57% of its market value this year, the company is grappling with collapsing commodity prices as slowing economic activity in China hits demand and wreaks havoc on markets.
Glencore's stock rose on the London Stock Exchange in early morning trading Wednesday on the back of the preferential right to purchase shares.
Shares rose 2.77% to 131.60 pence on the FTSE 100 index, which opened 0.69% higher.
Glencore has revealed plans to sell shares worth $2.5 billion as part of wider plans to cover almost a third of its $30 billion debt.
The company sold the new shares at 125 pence each, 2.4 percent below Tuesday's closing price.

Xi urges wider global economic expansion
President Xi Jinping said Tuesday to a group in charge of reform that the economy must open wider to the outside world to feed growth.
"China must engage in attracting foreign investment and expertise and improving its opening-up policies," Xi said at the 16th meeting of the Central Leading Group for Deepening Overall Reform.
Promoting openness and encouraging reforms will bring new impetus and vitality and make room for economic growth, Xi said.

The leadership group adopted a series of guidelines, including a negative list for market entry regulation, relaxing customs control policies, encouraging state-owned enterprises to absorb private capital and reorganizing the resident registration system.
The statement said a negative list will be drawn up to identify sectors and activities where investments are not permitted.
The system will be gradually tested and improved through trial programs.

The statement said the measure was important because it would give the market a greater role in the allocation of resources, ensuring a business environment based on legislation and providing more openness to the market.
The state will also ease controls on the powers it delegates to companies, ensuring that such companies decide how to run their businesses.
China will also allow border regions to explore new models of cross-border economic cooperation and new mechanisms to promote regional growth, the statement said.
In an effort to open up state-controlled sectors, more sectors will be opened to private investment.

"The state authorities will not change their policy on foreign investment and will protect the legitimate interests of foreign-invested companies and provide them with better services," the statement said.
In addition, it will be easier for foreign nationals to apply for permanent residence permits or so-called "green cards," streamlining requirements and speeding up the application process.
The meeting also discussed the guarantee of lawyers' right to practice, and the education of judges and prosecutors.
Premier Li Keqiang and leaders Liu Yunshan and Zhang Gaoli also attended the meeting, according to a statement issued after the meeting.

Ponta: In the future health and education will be the areas where we will invest all the money we have

According to him, a meeting of the FSLI will take place on Thursday with the participation of representatives of the Government to present to the representatives of the confederations in the country the proposal for wage increase, and the unionists will decide whether they accept the Executive's offer.
The prime minister also told the unionists that the government is trying to send the salary law as soon as possible to Parliament, so that it can come into force on December 1.
The bill provides for increasing the salaries in the educational system by 25% of the total 70% increase, which is to be phased in in the next four years.
Also, Victor Ponta promised trade unionists to pay in full the judicial sentences in 2016.

Air India is firing about 130 flight attendants for being overweight, the company announced late last week.

The state-run company said the decision was made for security reasons and recent government regulation, but critics say the measure is "ridiculous" and "shockingly sexist," The Washington Post reports.
The mass firing is the latest in a 10-year battle between the company and its fuller-figured flight attendants.
The weight limit dates back to the 1980s, when Air India started using charts of ideal weight and height.
In 2006, Air India fired nine stewardesses considered "exceptionally overweight," saying it could "affect their reflexes and agility required to perform emergency duties."
The flight attendants sued, won and were rehired, but the company fired them again in 2009.
"All efforts to get them to lose weight have failed," a company spokesman said at the time.
A Steaua football player gives lessons to Gigi Becali: What decision did he make
A Steaua footballer gives lessons to Gigi Becali about the promotion of young players.
If the financier of the champion decided to close the football academy in which he had invested a considerable amount, the defender Paul Papp opened a football school.
The "Paul Papp" Academy will operate in the city of Dej, the children from the locality are expected at a first selection action.
I am extremely happy to be at this stage with the launch of the Football Academy that bears my name.
For me, it is extremely important to find talented children who can play football without having to worry about material things at training.
They must have just one concern: that of playing football as well as possible.
The technical details should not be their concern.
They need to use their talent.
This is what the Paul Papp Football Academy wants to do.
"I'm waiting for the Mayor Costan Morar to come to the first selection of the kids, to show them he is with them," the footballer Papp told dejeanul.ro.
Children up to age 11 are expected at the Steaua soccer academy.
The party wants to govern.

The interim president of PSD, Liviu Dragnea, said on Tuesday that the entire party wants to remain in the government, and if the Prime Minister wants, this decision will be formalized at the PSD congress.
I understand that Mr. Ponta is waiting for this decision from the PSD Congress, everyone wants to be in power, the whole party.
If we want to formalize it through a congressional resolution, we will do so.
There will be no emotion about that.

"There have not been any elements, voices in the party, opinions in the party to give anyone uncertainty about the government or give anyone the impression that someone from the party does not want the PSD to remain in government, in the current government with the current prime minister," Dragnea said at the end of the PSD's National Permanent Bureau meeting.
PSD announced when it will hold congress - what will be decided then

Prime Minister Victor Ponta said on Tuesday that it is important that, at the PSD Congress, aside from electing the leadership, a clear message is given as to whether the party wants to continue governing or decides to move into the opposition.
Dragnea: I will announce Monday if I will run for a position at Congress
On the other hand, Liviu Dragnea will announce next Monday if he will run for a leadership position at the future Congress.
I will weigh in on Monday, after the Executive Committee, if the congress date is also set.
"I will announce if I will run for a position in the party leadership", Dragnea said at the end of the Tuesday meeting of the PSD National Permanent Bureau.
