Asked if his hesitation to announce his candidacy was related to his case, Dragnea said he didn't have such a problem.
I don't have the problem you're talking about, but I think it's fair and honest to my colleagues in the party to announce or not a candidacy at the time the formal date of the Congress is set.
"This is the only motivation," Dragnea said.

The vast majority of social-democratic branches have proposed an extraordinary congress of the PSD on October 11, and the exact date of the congress will be decided on Monday by the party's Executive Committee.
Career Fair Offers Thousands of Jobs at 200 Companies
200 companies are expected at the autumn edition of Career Fair (TdC), an event that will take place in Brasov, Chisinau, Cluj-Napoca, Iasi, Sibiu and Tirgu-Mures.
The companies have several thousand job vacancies, internship opportunities and traineeships, and some of them have already been announced on the official website www.targuldecariere.ro.
Recruiting Becoming a Greater Priority for Companies

According to the statistics gathered during the 100 editions of the Career Fair so far, most companies are interested, besides the actual recruitment, to develop a strong employer brand among young people: 97% of their representatives said they wanted to return to the future editions, while 94% declared that they recommend TdC as a recruitment and employer branding solution.
There are also cases where companies choose to make the hiring in batches, so that they can think more organized about their recruitment.

Among the companies that will be present at the TdC in October and November 2015 are: Arvato Bertelsmann, Bombardier, Bosch, CIE Matricon, Competence Call Center, DB Schenker, Delphi, Office Depot, Preh, Renault, Schaeffler, Stefanini and Sykes.
TdC candidate profile
Most of the TdC participants looking for a job are students, 59.70%, followed by graduates - 23.05% and master graduates: 10.38%.
The least educated are those with a PhD - 0.67 - and young people who have completed high school or elementary school - 6.20%.

In terms of specializations, most of them work in IT and Software, in the banking and financial sector or in insurance, marketing, advertising and media or in the automotive and construction industry.
It is no longer a novelty that the IT sector is in a continuous ascension in the country.
As a result, another edition of the IT Career Fair will be held this year, a niche event dedicated exclusively to the enthusiasts and specialists in this field.
Among the business giants present at the 7th edition of the event are Accenture, Endava, KFC, McDonald's, msg systems, Siemens, Steelcase, Unicredit Business Integrated Solutions and Yardi Systems.
Careers Fair, 100 editions
Founded in Cluj in 2006, the Career Fair is today the largest career events network in Romania and the Republic of Moldova.

The autumn edition will take place in Chisinau (Army House, 2-3 October), Iasi (Palas, 6-7 October), Brasov (Army House, 14-15 October), Cluj Global (Polyvalent Hall, 20-21 October), Cluj IT (Polyvalent Hall, 22-23 October), Sibiu (Business Center, 28-29 October) and Targu-Mures (National Theatre, 5 November).
Details about the companies registered so far and about the Career Fair can be found on www.targuldecariere.ro.
An Italian was caught at the Bors border crossing with immigrants hidden in a truck
Two Sri Lankan citizens were caught at the Bors border crossing on Monday as they were trying to cross the border illegally, hidden in the trailer of a truck driven by an Italian citizen.
During investigations it was found that the two had paid the driver 4,000 euros to be transported to France, the Border Police informs.

During the routine check, border police noticed a large travel bag in the truck's cabin, containing personal belongings for several people, which prompted them to carry out a thorough check of the transport vehicle.
During the check, border police discovered, hidden in the trailer of the truck, two male persons, among the plastic crates.
The checks showed that the two men, aged 28, are citizens of Sri Lanka and asylum seekers in Romania.

"During the investigations, the young people stated that they wanted to go to France, for which they contacted a compatriot, through whom they met the Italian driver, who offered to carry them to the destination, where they had to receive 2,000 euros per person," the Border Police said in a statement.
The two migrants were indicted for "attempting to illegally cross the state border."

Also, Pompeo B., a 45-year-old Italian citizen who was driving a Renault Magnum truck registered in Romania and carrying plastic containers for an Italian company, was detained for 24 hours and will be presented to the Bihor Tribunal with a proposal for preventive arrest.
How satisfied are Romanians in a couple: Men versus women
Most Romanians are satisfied with their relationships.
This is the conclusion of a study conducted on the occasion of John Gray's visit in Romania, the famous author of the bestseller "Men are from Mars, Women are from Venus".
A total of 62 percent of respondents said they were 'very satisfied' or 'satisfied' with the overall quality of their relationship.

"However, 18 percent said they were 'slightly dissatisfied' and 'very dissatisfied' with their relationship, while 18 percent said they were 'just right'", the study concluded, according to a statement sent to Ziare.com on Tuesday.
The situation is somewhat different when men's and women's responses are analyzed separately.
Thus, 28% of men are very satisfied, 39% satisfied, 17% ok, 6% very dissatisfied and 8% slightly dissatisfied.
As for the women, 33% were satisfied, 24% very satisfied, 8% very unsatisfied, 14% slightly unsatisfied and 19% chose the appropriate category.
When we look at the degree of satisfaction (positive), we will observe that men are more satisfied.
As for the neutral state (fair), we see a two percent difference.
"The same is true with the very unsatisfied situation, the biggest difference being registered in the slightly unsatisfied response where we see a difference of 6 percent," the report also said.
The study also found that a quarter of Romanians (26%) spend an hour or less together, 18% spend between five and eight hours together and 45% spend between two and four hours together.

The study's authors also said "Romanians feel the need for a little more adventure in their lives (24%), followed by affection (21%), money (21%), safety (20%), new (19%), sex (19%), respect 18%, trust 17%, pleasure 17%, connection 17%, knowledge 16%, protection 14%, importance 14%, learning 12%, freedom 11%, self-knowledge 10% and control 7%."
The study was conducted by Extreme Training from June 1 to September 1 on 1,369 people, with a margin of error of 2.6 percent.
Europe has embarrassed itself again

German Vice Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel said Tuesday that Europe "brought shame upon itself" after Monday's failure of a ministerial meeting in Brussels on the relocation of refugees within the European Union.
"Last night, Europe made itself a laughingstock yet again," said Sigmar Gabriel, who is also economy minister in Chancellor Angela Merkel's government, AFP reported.
Earlier, German Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere suggested reducing EU structural funds for countries that reject refugee quotas.

European interior ministers failed to reach a deal on Monday on the mandatory distribution of 120,000 refugees, requested last week by the European Commission to address one of the worst migration crises in Europe since 1945.
He was mayor for only half an hour
The interim mayor of the Tuzla commune in Constanta county has only enjoyed his position for a half an hour, because of prosecutors with the National Anti-Corruption Directorate.
Taner Resit was appointed as the mayor of the locality, replacing former mayor, Constantin Micu, sentenced for embezzlement, B1 TV informs.
The county prefect, Ion Constantin, was waiting for him at the county's headquarters to make the official announcement at 4 p.m., but he did not arrive.
Why?
Taner Resit was summoned at 14.00 at the DNA Constanta headquarters.
After two and a half hours of hearings, he was detained for 24 hours.
As a result, he was mayor for only 30 minutes.
Prosecutors say he is accused of extorting a businessman from August 16 to September 8, in complicity with Stefan Radu, a businessman who wanted to get 48,000 euros from him, Adevarul reports.
The two men threatened the manager, drove away customers, prevented them from entering the store, changed the locks and sequestered the company's goods.
Moreover, on September 8, Stefan Radu would have beaten the administrator, in the presence of the deputy mayor.
Thousands of people passed by to place a candle

Thousands of people have passed by the casket with the lifeless body of Corneliu Vadim Tudor, more people being at St. George Church than at the consecration of the church or at the Great Feast of St. Nicholas, said on Wednesday the priest Emil Caramizaru.
Hundreds of people of all ages queue up, stretching from the church entrance to the side streets, to pass by the catafalque on which the lifeless body of Corneliu Vadim Tudor lies.
People wait for about an hour to get into the New St. George Church, where groups of 40 people are let in.
About 300 people per hour have passed by the coffin of Corneliu Vadim Tudor on Wednesday.

Thousands of people from Bucharest, but also from Cluj, Baia Mare, Iasi, Constanta and Craiova came on Tuesday to pay tribute to Corneliu Vadim Tudor, we have not had so many people only at the re-consecration of the 300 years of the church and at the Great Feast of Saint Nicholas.

"Corneliu Vadim Tudor was at the 300th anniversary of the church and he stood next to the members of the Holy Synod, His Beatitude Daniel and representatives of the five patriarchs who attended the anniversary", said the parish priest of the church in Bucharest, Emil Caramizaru.
According to him, people come with flowers and candles in hand, they stand quietly and wait in line, as if it were a religious holiday.
The behavior of these people is extraordinary, they sit quietly, with dignity, children, old people, people in crutches, as if they were at a great religious celebration.
"It is touching to see them waiting to pay their last respects to Vadim Tudor," parish priest Emil Caramizaru said.

According to him, at the request of Corneliu Vadim Tudor's family, the church will stay open on the night from Wednesday to Thursday, the previous night being closed at 01:00 and reopened in the morning at 07:00.

He said on Thursday morning at 10.00am, at the St. George Church at kilometer 0, there will be a brief service, after which the coffin with the body of Vadim Tudor will be transported to Ghencea Civil Cemetery, where the funeral service will take place, with a religious and military ceremony.

The parish priest said that Vadim Tudor came to the church often, especially in the evening, after 20:00, and then he asked him to open the reliquary with the relics of St. Nicholas and he remained to pray for minutes.
He used to come here very often, usually in the evening, after 8 p.m., he would ask me to open the reliquary with the relics of Saint Nicholas and he would pray.
He said it was a great blessing this church of Brancoveanu.
He told me: "Think, dear brother Emil, that here were Brancoveanu, Eminescu, Mihai Viteazul, who carried the hand of St. Nicholas."
"'Can you imagine what a blessing it is for this country,' Vadim told me," the parish priest said.
Corneliu Vadim Tudor will be buried on Thursday at the Ghencea Civil Cemetery, with military honors.
The Senate leadership on Tuesday rejected a request by Corneliu Vadim Tudor's wife that the late senator's coffin be laid in the legislative chamber.
Corneliu Vadim Tudor was born on November 28, 1949 in Bucharest, he was a writer, politician and journalist.
He was the founder of the Greater Romania Party, a former member of the European Parliament and a former senator.
What's happening with Darren Cahill
Simona Halep is facing a crucial decision for her career, having to choose whether to continue working with coach Darren Cahill.
The two have worked together this year as part of the Adidas Player Development program, and the Australian coach has been with the Romanian player only at the major tournaments.
Simona only had praise for Cahill, who appears to be the only coach who has managed to impose himself on the capricious player.
However, the Adidas program will end at the end of this year, and Halep will have to decide whether to give Cahill a substantial contract or break the collaboration.
We don't know what will happen yet.
We'll see.
"After Singapore I will be able to give an answer", Simona said at a press conference.
Darren Cahill is one of the highest-paid coaches in tennis, asking for a contract worth about $1 million a year.
In addition, the Australian is a sports commentator, a job he does not want to give up at the moment.
The last competition Simona and Cahill will work together is the WTA Finals in Singapore.
It wasn't normal, I wasn't respected
Victor Piturca revealed how he parted ways with the Romanian national team last fall.

The former coach admitted that he did not get along with the president of the Romanian Football Federation, Razvan Burleanu, after he took the place of Mircea Sandu, and thus he decided to leave the national team.
Finally, he offered the federation president to increase his salary substantially in order to stay, but was refused.
Right now I don't regret leaving the national team.
At the time I felt sorry, leaving a job behind.
So I thought it was good for me, and I think it was good for me.
What happened to me when I was the coach, it wasn't normal, I wasn't respected, my work wasn't respected.

I worked well with the people at the federation before, but when Burleanu came at the federation he came with a preconceived idea, he didn't know me, he heard different opinions about me from the press.
I did not change because it was very hard at that moment, with the results that we had, plus the financial situation.
We continued working, everything went well and probably he changed his mind.
But I wanted to leave.
If they really wanted me to stay, I proposed a contract extension.
We have around 400 thousand euros per year, I was supposed to have around 600 thousand euros.
I have not talked with Burleanu, but with his right hand.
"He agreed, but only if we finish first in the group," Victor Piturca told Dolce Sport.
Victor Piturca resigned from the Romanian national team in the fall of last year, although the team had good results in the preliminaries of Euro 2016.
The technician accepted the proposal to coach in Saudi Arabia, immediately taking over Al Ittihad.
Tanks and Water Cannons at the Border

Hungarian police have deployed Humvee military vehicles equipped with machine guns to the border with Serbia after violent clashes Wednesday, when water cannons and tear gas were used against migrants trying to enter from Serbia, despite Hungary having built a razor wire border fence.
At least 20 police officers and two children were injured in the clashes, Russia Today reports.
So far 20 police officers have been injured and the ambulance service has taken two children who were injured after being thrown over the security fence.
"We will rebuild the fence and strengthen it and we will protect Hungary's security by all means," said Hungarian Prime Minister's security adviser Gyorgy Bakondi.
Police tried to control the crowd with water cannons and tear gas as people threw plastic bottles, stones and chunks of pavement.
Authorities reported that dozens of migrants broke through a fence between the towns of Roszke and Horgos and managed to enter the country.
Hungary's Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto has called on Serbia to take measures against "very aggressive" migrants on their common border.
There are reports that the Serbs have beefed up border security forces.
Following Wednesday's incidents, Budapest suspended the border crossing at Roszke-Horgos for 30 days.
Hungary is in a concerted effort to close its borders to stem the flow of migrants.

After announcing on Tuesday that he would build a fence along the border with Serbia, to the vehement protests of Bucharest, the Hungarian prime minister announced that he would also put up a fence at the border with Croatia.
Rare Disease Suffers Man
American Nick Hess was suspected by his family of being an alcoholic, his wife even filming him when he was drunk, barely able to stand, and slurring his words.
Although the 35-year-old man said that he had not consumed alcohol, it was obvious he was drunk.
When she first accused me of being drunk, while I hadn't had a drink, I thought she was crazy.
"But friends and family thought 'maybe he's drinking on his own, he's a secret alcoholic,'" he told the Mirror.
When he watched the videos of his wife with him, the Columbus, Ohio, man simply didn't recognize himself: "I was looking into my eyes and I wasn't there."
'It was horrible, I didn't remember anything.'
In addition, his wife, who, although she had doubted him for a while, eventually went with him to innumerable doctors, remembers that Nick's breath smelled of alcohol.

The moment that really made Nick think was when, after a minor accident, in which he was hit by another car, it was discovered that he had an alcohol level three times over the legal limit, even though the night before he had only had one beer.
After years and countless investigations, it was discovered that Nick suffers from an extremely rare disease, "Auto-brewery syndrome".
Essentially, its body makes all the carbohydrates it eats ferment, turning them into alcohol.
The one who suspected that this might be Nick's disease was his wife.
The disease has no cure, but since giving up carbohydrates, Nick has not had any such episodes.
He destroyed a Mercedes with a golf club
A South Korean man has destroyed his S63 Mercedes in a protest against the service he received from his dealer.
The man attacked his car with a golf club, causing enough damage to make the car unusable, BT reports.
The entire scene was filmed and the video was posted on the Internet, to the amusement of those who saw it.
The man claimed that the car had defects that put his life and his family's lives in danger.
His anger erupted when the dealer he bought the car from failed to resolve the problem, as they had agreed.

The government on Wednesday approved the "National Immigration Strategy for the period 2015-2018" and the "Action Plan for 2015", documents considered to be "yet another stage in the process of modernizing the management of immigration on Romania’s territory", according to a press release.

The source said the strategy aims at managing immigration efficiently, including general strategic objectives, specific objectives and action lines that reflect the policies established at the European level, adapted to the national realities.

Given the problems faced by states in Romania's immediate neighborhood, measures are being considered for the unified and coherent management of situations caused by the possible appearance of an influx of illegal immigrants on Romanian territory, generated by political, social, economic or military crisis situations.

"Romanian authorities will contribute to creating a flexible admission system, but at the same time will pay special attention to citizens coming from states with migration potential or who may affect national security," the source added.

The strategy identifies a number of factors that can influence immigration and asylum, including the ongoing conflict in Syria, the reactivation of the conflict in Iraq, the maintenance of an unstable situation in the neighboring areas of Romania (Ukraine, Transnistria), the perpetuation and increased intensity of the Israeli-Palestinian armed conflict.

The document also sets forth several general strategic objectives related to immigration, such as: promoting legal migration, more stringent controls on the legal residence of third-country nationals on Romanian territory and the proper application of removal and restrictive measures, improving the national asylum system.
The national strategy also includes specific objectives relevant for the transposition and implementation of the general strategic objectives.

These include: facilitating the entry into Romania of third country nationals to meet the needs of the labor market, encouraging access of third country nationals to higher education institutions in Romania for the fields and professions identified as being in shortage.

Regarding the Action Plan for 2015, the Government considers that it represents "a means by which concrete activities are established that will lead to the creation of a flexible system for stopping the growing migration phenomenon".
Romania, in a European labor market top

Latvia, Romania and Bulgaria have recorded the highest increase in the total labour cost among EU member states, in the second quarter of the year, compared to the same period in 2014, according to data published on Wednesday by the European Statistics Office (Eurostat).
The index refers to employers' personnel expenses.
Thus, in the period April-June 2015, the total cost of labour rose by 1.9% in the European Union and by 1.6% in the euro zone.
Romania ranks 3rd in EU in labor cost growth
The largest increases were reported in Latvia (7.9%), Romania (7.7%), Bulgaria (6.8%), Estonia (5.5%) and Lithuania (4.3%).
The only EU states where the hourly labour cost fell in the second quarter of this year were Greece (minus 2.9%), Cyprus (minus 1.2%) and Italy (minus 0.4%).
The rise in labour costs in Romania in the April – June 2015 period is mainly due to the increase in hourly labour costs in industry and services, by 7.9% and 7.6%, respectively.
In the construction sector, Romania recorded an increase of 5.8% in hourly labor costs.
TVR management activity report rejected in committees: Stelian Tanase risks dismissal
The culture committees of the Parliament rejected on Wednesday the activity report of the Board of Administration of the Romanian Television Society for 2014.
Seventeen lawmakers voted to reject the report, one voted against rejecting it (Senator Varujan Vosganian) and one abstained.
The report will be forwarded to the Joint Standing Committees.
They are expected to decide next week.
It will be debated at the next plenary session.
"I believe, given this situation, it will be done fairly quickly", said the head of the Senate Culture Committee, Georgica Severin.

He added that "it was common sense" for the TVR leadership to be present at this meeting, considering that no representative of the TVR leadership was present at the meeting of the Culture Committees.
It would have been common sense for the management of TVR to be present because no one here has been subjected to personal attacks or anything like that.

The invitation was made to the members of the Board of Directors last night, with an approximate time because we didn't know the time either, but today, after the joint meeting of the Bureaus, personally I sent a fax to the leadership of the TVR inviting them.
I believe that when you are summoned, being a public servant, paid from public taxes and you are summoned to a meeting of the joint committees, even if you don't like it you come.
"It is your duty, you are in an institution under the Parliament", Severin said after the meeting of the Culture Committees of the Parliament.
He added that the meeting discussed the financial aspects of the institution based on the negative opinion of the Budget Committees.
Well, we've seen debts continue, the idea came that this year they would be up to date, but the historical ones have not been paid.

"I'll remind you that it wasn't my fault or the fault of any of the other committees that we lost that agreement with the banks and the tax authorities, this is a clear management problem," Severin said.
He said that after the activity report is rejected by the joint plenum, elections will be held for a new Board of Directors, which will elect the institution's general director.
I don't know who will be proposed for this position.
Miracles will not happen.
It is important to take political decisions for this institution to function.
I'm not going to lie to you and say that a genius is going to arrive and stand in line and fight.
I hope that those who decide, the parliament, through their vote will choose wisely the people who will lead the TVR.
There must be people who know what's going on there, have experience and have a lot of fairness and respect for the institution and tradition.
I don't know who will be, if you ask me what qualities he should have - common sense in attitude towards employees because there is a heap of petitions coming from employees, complaints, dismissal.
"When you have 50, 60, 70 complaints, something is rotten and we are talking about a financial situation which is a disaster," the president of the Senate's culture commission concluded.

Although he did not attend Parliament, the CEO of TVR, Stelian Tanase, sent a letter to the president of the Chamber of Deputies, Valeriu Zgonea, in which he requested that Parliament consider a series of measures that could lead to the saving and guaranteeing of the economic and political independence of the public television. Among these measures is the indexing of the TV tax.

In the letter, Stelian Tanase requested, besides the indexation of the TV tax, the modification and completion of HG 978/2003 concerning the tax for the public television service, in the sense of updating the provisions at the level of today's technological changes, as well as for the regulation of the procedure for controlling the payment of the TV tax and the detection of contraventions and the application of sanctions and penalties.
He also wants to issue a provision requiring all electricity suppliers to become SRTv tax collectors, involving ANRE in the regulation of this activity.
He believes that a cap of 5% commission on collections is necessary.

Stelian Tanase is asking for a reduction of the VAT for the activities specific to the public television station and of the contribution for the CNC from 15% to 3%, but also for a modification of the law 41/1994, in the sense of being able to receive budgetary allocations/funding for the purchase of licenses for major cultural and sports events - the World Football Championship, the Golden Stag, Eurovision.

He claims SRTv will go bankrupt in the coming months because labor legislation obliges the employer to enforce court decisions, even if they are not final, and wage rights are honored before any other obligation.
The TVR administration has constantly made efforts to reduce personnel and TV production costs.

"Thus, business trips and other cost-generating activities have been reduced, a number of commercial contracts have been renegotiated, and at the end of July the TVR News channel was closed," the TVR president said in the letter.
Tanase believes that the disastrous financial situation cannot be remedied only by his own efforts.

"Without support from the state institutions - the Government, Parliament, the Presidency - Romanian Television will sooner or later find itself unable to fulfill its public mission," the letter reads.
The Chamber of Deputies' leadership decided to send the letter to the Culture Committee.
Vasile Blaga's son-in-law on trial
Vasile Blaga's son-in-law, Ionut Andrei Rudeanu, was indicted on Wednesday by prosecutors of the Bucharest Court of Appeal.
He is accused of tax evasion in a case involving damages of about 600,000 euros, and is under judicial control.
Andrei Rudeanu was arrested on May 22.
He set up the security firm Axis Corporate Security SRL, along with his mother, in April 2009, one year after he married Vasile Blaga's daughter Agathe.

According to the investigation, in order to avoid paying taxes to the state budget, representatives of a company specializing in security services would have created a criminal circuit, consisting of several commercial companies, through which fictitious transactions would have been evidenced.

"In fact, in the company's accountancy fictitious purchases of services were recorded, which in reality were not provided and the state budget was thus prejudiced by about 600,000 euros", the Romanian Police explained in a press release.
Sheikhs have decided Sanmartean's fate
Al-Ittihad bosses have decided the fate of Lucian Sanmartean.
Although the Arab press announced that Sanmartean's separation from Ittihad is imminent, the player's agent Ladislau Boloni, Arcadie Zaporojanu, says this will not happen.
Boloni is very pleased with Sanmartean.
Lucian is playing starter in every match, and he is doing well.
The sheikhs realized that he is the best and that it would be a mistake if they gave up on him.
He could have brought another player, a much better one, but nothing came out.
"There have been several discussions, such as one with Mbark Boussoufa, but nothing has materialized," Zaporojanu told Digi Sport.
Lucian Sanmartean came to Al-Ittihad at the beginning of this year.
Ilie Sarbu was elected vice-president of the Court of Accounts
The Senate voted Wednesday to appoint PSD Senator Ilie Sarbu, the father-in-law of Prime Minister Victor Ponta, as vice president of the Audit Authority of the Court of Accounts.
There were 290 votes "for" and 108 against, according to Mediafax.
The vote was secret, with ballots.
PNL representatives were the only ones to vote against the proposal, Digi24 informs.

The liberals had criticized Sarbu's appointment and announced they would challenge it at the Constitutional Court, as he has a file with the National Anti-Corruption Department but lacks the necessary training and experience.
Ilie Sarbu has 30 days, according to law, to resign from the Senate, as his new position at the Court of Accounts does not allow him to do politics anymore.

The PSD Senator will take the position of vice president of the Audit Authority of the Court of Accounts, left vacant after Ioan Anton was dismissed, following a decision of the Constitutional Court in September 2014, which ruled that he was appointed unconstitutionally.
Surprise from one of the sexiest actors: I grew up in the kitchen
As Bradley Cooper is set to play a chef in the upcoming film "Burnt", the actor made a surprising revelation about his character that his fans weren't expecting.
In a recent interview, he said he grew up more in the kitchen: "I worked most of my life as a cook."
He revealed that he had been working in the kitchen since he was 15, when he worked for a Greek restaurant, and then continued the same path in college.
The actor explained that his mother is Italian, so he spent his childhood cooking with his Italian grandmother, ContactMusic reports.
Asked what his future plans were at the time, Bradley Cooper said he had never been the kind of person to make plans five years out, "or even two."
"It's not motivating for me to have a map," he said.
"I have dreams, things you'd laugh at if I told you," he said, adding that what he wanted as a child has come true.
At 40 years old, the actor does admit that he sees himself directing in the near future, taking a cue from Clint Eastwood, who started directing at the same age.
Ponta accused of uncontrolled calumnies and irrational statements

Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto on Wednesday slammed Romanian Prime Minister Victor Ponta's statements that Hungarian political decision-makers are "no better than those in Syria, Libya or other countries where refugees are fleeing from."
"Yesterday, Victor Ponta lost his self-control and, with his irrational statements, he offended the entire Hungary," the Hungarian Foreign Minister said in a statement.
Civilized European politicians do not utter such uncontrolled slander.
"His remarks have only one explanation: he has lost all support in internal politics in Romania," the Hungarian foreign minister added, MTI reported.

In a Facebook post on Tuesday night, Prime Minister Victor Ponta said he wanted to call attention to and sanction the behaviour of high-ranking Hungarian government officials, who, in his opinion, "are a disgrace to the culture and values of the European Union".
I do not want to respond to provocations coming from some Hungarian government representatives.

"They are a shame for the culture and values of the European Union; both in their anti-Semitic attitudes and in their treatment of minorities of all kinds and now in the refugee crisis!", Ponta said on Facebook.
The Romanian prime minister added that he is an advocate of rational and sustainable solutions to the refugee crisis, saying that brutality and aggressive laws will not solve the problem.

Barbed wire, aggressive laws, prisons and brutality will not solve the problem - they will only show that in Hungary, in the heart of Europe, there are political leaders who are no better than those in Syria, Libya, or other countries from which the refugees flee!

"I believe in solidarity, in rational and sustainable solutions and especially in the superiority of European values - what we are seeing in Hungary these days is in total contradiction with these objectives and values!", the Romanian Prime Minister emphasized.

Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto on Tuesday dismissed as "simple lies" Romanian Prime Minister Victor Ponta's remarks on Hungary's handling of the refugee crisis, saying that such statements are unfit for a 21st-century leader, MTI reported.

The Hungarian foreign minister also said Tuesday that "extremist and false" remarks of the Romanian prime minister are related to Romania's internal political crisis, and added that Budapest is expecting an apology from the Romanian side.
Szijjarto referred to a statement made Monday by Prime Minister Victor Ponta.

What I have always said and I continue to say is that I am against xenophobic speeches, the idea of closing borders, that everyone who comes is a terrorist, that they are medieval idiots and I totally oppose this approach.
If we can get more, we will get more, the problem is our logistical capacity to treat them as human beings, not as our Hungarian neighbors treat them, with a baton and with pepper spray.
"I don't agree with that", the Romanian prime minister said at a press conference in Targu-Jiu.

On Tuesday, Peter Szijjarto announced that the government in Budapest has decided to begin preparations to extend the fence at the border with Romania, to handle a possible change in the route used by refugees.
Later, Prime Minister Victor Ponta said that Hungary's decision to erect a fence on its border does not solve the refugee crisis, and "takes Hungary out of Europe."
What is the connection between Osama bin Laden and the Mecca crane collapse?

Saudi authorities said Saudi construction giant Binladin Group, owned by Osama bin Laden's family, is "partially responsible" for the collapse of a crane at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Friday, which killed 107 people.
According to an investigation committee, the company did not "meet safety standards", the Saudi Press Agency (SPA) reported, BBC reports.
Company executives have been banned from leaving the country pending the outcome of the investigation.
The company will also be barred from new public contracts.
The construction firm is owned by the family of former al-Qaida terror network leader Osama bin Laden.
The company was founded by Osama bin Laden's father 80 years ago and is now run by the former terror leader's brother, Bakr.
The Binladen Group has been working for four years on the expansion of the Grand Mosque to accommodate more pilgrims.
The accident occurred Friday evening during a thunderstorm when a crane, apparently unbalanced by strong winds, toppled onto the eastern side of the Grand Mosque in Mecca.
The accident left 107 people dead and nearly 400 injured.
How Hagi shut up the protesters
Widely considered to be the greatest Romanian footballer of all time, Gica Hagi was labeled, after retiring from playing, as a weak coach, who could not achieve success in his new position.
After unsuccessful experiences at the national team, Steaua or Galatasaray, Hagi took over, a year ago, the role of coach at Viitorul Constanta, the team he owns.
After one year at the helm, the King proved he is capable to transform a team struggling to avoid relegation into a top team.
So, after one year, Viitorul registered, with Hagi as coach, 16 wins, 11 draws and 11 defeats.
The balance is that of a top team that fights for the European cups.
Things have been looking even better for Viitorul in this season, as the team is now ranked second in Liga 1, with 19 points, one less than leaders Astra Giurgiu.
Future has the best attack in the League 1, with 20 goals (tied with Astra), more than double than Steaua.

On the other hand, even if he brought more experienced players to the team, Hagi continued the policy of promoting youngsters and in recent times names like Ianis Hagi or Hodorogea appeared in the starting lineup.

The club's policy has made Viitorul a team to watch for foreign teams, so Hagi sold this summer for 1.5 million euros - Ianis Hagi (Fiorentina - 1 million euros) and Alexandru Mitrita (Bari - 500 thousand euros).
Along with Steaua, Viitorul is the only profitable team in Liga 1, according to the data from the Trade Register.
In the refugee crisis, Romania has so far played as a small country.
It's a legitimate strategy, but after that you can't ask to be treated as the seventh country of the EU.
The big countries are coming up with solutions for the whole EU, says Cristian Ghinea, member of the board of directors of the Romanian Centre for European Policies.

In an interview with Ziare.com, Cristian Ghinea said that Europe cannot be converted into a fortress, and pure police methods will not work in this crisis: "Maybe we have doubts about the quality of the values that these people bring."
But there are masses that have started and we can not turn back history.
Migration is a reality that we must adapt to as best as we can and adapt them to us.
According to Cristian Ghinea, we are in an extremely emotional moment, in which politicians feel the need to show their muscles.

After he passes, Europeans will not be willing to give up on free movement, but the rules in the Schengen zone need to be changed: "Schengen is now like an animal created in a different era and that was not adapted to today's situation."
Where are we in the refugee crisis after this JAI Council that, in fact, did not solve anything?
It is clear that the EC president in agreement with Donald Tusk did not want to force a vote in the council.
All the polls said he had the necessary votes.
Before the Lisbon Treaty, the JHA operated on the principle of unanimity and any state could block any decision.
So, things have been very little integrated in the field of justice and home affairs.

After Lisbon, the normal procedure applies, whereby the Commission has the initiative, and the council approves it with the vote of 55% of the states, i.e. 16, which represent 65% of the EU's population.
The math said the votes were there.
But they didn't want to go ahead.

Because it's a sensitive matter, there have been reactions of rejection even in Germany against Chancellor Merkel's policy of opening and they did not want in many countries a reaction of the type "EU sends us migrants on our heads".
So they have postponed it, but the problem remains because obviously this wave creates a huge problem for Schengen governance and we will probably see big changes there in the coming period.
So the mandatory quotas were not actually eliminated, the subject was just left to cool down?

Yes, on the other hand, there is talk of greater involvement of the Frontex agency in the management of external borders, which means a change from the individual responsibility of the members who are at the external border of the Schengen area to the responsibility of the community agencies.
The Greek border with Turkey is also the German border with Turkey, de facto, and this wave of migrants has given the limits of the old Schengen system.
The Dublin principle, under which migrants are the responsibility of the first country they enter, may be scrapped because it is not sustainable.
If Greece goes down, you can't say forever that it's Greece's problem.
The problem is common.
Since the problem is common, is it possible to solve it without a precise, maybe even mandatory, mechanism for the sharing of the effort of reception?
No one knows exactly how the quotas will work, if they are introduced.
But there is still a problem: what do you do with someone who doesn't want to come to Romania or Portugal, but to Sweden or Germany?
I don't think that European countries will start taking migrants: you go to country X or country Y.
Probably there will be some central filtration centers, in Greece or in Turkey, where the asylum applications will be processed.
Work is being done on solutions like this.
But the problem does not have a simple solution.

There are countries that have decades of experience in trying to integrate migrants, there are countries with no experience, like Romania, where the migrant issue will increase the xenophobic current.
What is certain is that we are talking about millions of people who are in Turkey, in Lebanon, in Jordan, who are in precarious camps and who have just started to come to Europe.
An estimate says only 10% have managed to leave, winter is hard to cross the Mediterranean, but we expect next year a wave even larger.
What do we do with these people?
My forecast is that we will get used to this problem, we will not view it as catastrophic from a media point of view.
You spoke about countries with more or less experience.
Do you think there is any place where the integration of large groups from a non-European culture has really succeeded?
I look at the Maghrebis in France, the Turks in Germany, they're all ghettoized.
I would not go to radical statements.
Sure, their integration is more difficult than in the case of other waves of migration, but that doesn't mean that they don't integrate at all.
There is a part that remains un-integrated that causes major social problems in France, in Germany, in Britain.
But police-state measures won't work.
Creating a fortress Europe is an illusion.
Mechanisms of integration into European societies need to be improved.
There were some mistakes here.
We need to be more demanding.

Let's ask these people to learn the language, to try to take on the values, not to remain with one foot in Europe and one in their country of origin, bringing the rest of their families here, even through convenient marriages.
But the immediate problem of these people must be separated from the long-term problem of their integration.
If others have failed in long-term integration it doesn't mean we should watch them drown in the Mediterranean.
Maybe we have doubts about the quality of the values that these people come with.
And if there is an intervention in Syria, which I don't think there will be, that doesn't mean the country will be rebuilt overnight and you can take them back.
Until we find solutions, we will see fortresses inside Europe.
Borders are being closed, walls are being built, border controls are being reintroduced in the Schengen space.
Is the European project in danger?
The European project as such, no. The Schengen space as it was built, yes.
It was built quite minimal, and arranging the rules so that the pressure was too great on the countries where these migrants first set foot.
So we move around freely, but each of us has our own problems.
In the face of such a wave, some countries cannot handle it.
When there are such waves of emotion, politicians want to show that they are doing something, but in the long run nothing much changes.
After the attacks in France we do not have a much more draconian anti-terror legislation in the EU than we had last year.
It's a wave of public emotion that is settling in both directions.
And it's so unstable from week to week that you can't make decisions based on it.
We have a lot of talk, lots of belligerent statements from politicians at home under pressure to be macho.
And then you have the dramatic case of the drowned child in Turkey and the public becomes emotional.
After the public emotion passes, we will return to the reasons why we created this space, this freedom of movement that is not only for people, but also for goods.
This is the single European real market.
And I don't think the Europeans will give up on this principle of freedom of movement.
That there will be other rules is another thing.
Schengen is now like an animal that was created in another era and was not adapted to the current situation.
How has Romania played so far in this crisis?
As a small country, which believes that if it pulls the cap over its eyes and plugs its ears, the problem disappears.
In the face of the reality of the waves of migrants, you can choose to be part of the solution or say that it is not your problem as a small country.
We did that, it's a legitimate strategy, but then you can't ask to be treated as the seventh country of the EU.
You are not, you don't play at the level of a big country.
The big countries come up with solutions for the entire EU, good or bad, we are not discussing their quality now.
As Poland did.
On the other hand, the effect of this crisis is that Romanians' appetite for Schengen will decrease very much.
President Iohannis says that maybe it's good that we haven't entered yet.
So we move from the despair of entry to a more pragmatic position, but the goal remains the same.
There is of course a risk if Romania and Bulgaria enter Schengen that migrants will see us as an alternative route.
This doesn't mean we shouldn't enter Schengen, but that we should be more pragmatic.

Romania will be part of Schengen, and Schengen will exist, but transformed in the sense that the external borders will become a common responsibility, there will be unified rules for accepting migrants, unified rules for deporting those who do not receive asylum, unified rules for the countries considered safe.
Ukraine's President says since Russia shifted its attention to Syria, no one has died in Ukraine.
Is there a link between the two outbreaks, a game of Russia?
Russia has a behavior of a frustrated power.
She believes that being a great power means annoying the Americans and the Europeans.
In that sense, yes, there is a link.
Without Putin's military and financial support, the Assad regime would probably have collapsed long ago.
And it was better that it collapsed before its main opponent was the Islamic State.
For about two years it was a battle between the Assad regime and secular and moderate Muslim militias, backed by Gulf states and the West.
Then the Islamic State came along and now we don't know if we want the Assad regime to fall.
Russia could complicate things, but it cannot participate in the solution.
It creates hotspots of instability and chaos which it cannot close.
But you're a great power only if you have solutions.
Playing offside is just a strategy to win time.
Putin is probably waiting for an offer, to push buttons to resolve the situation.
The offers aren't coming because the world isn't convinced that he can resolve the problems he created.
But I do not agree with the theories that these people are driven by an invisible hand.
Let's not see Putin stronger than he is.
What button will appear soon
Millions of Facebook users have become accustomed to the "Like" button, and now, the social network's representatives are preparing another one, the "Dislike" button.
Mark Zuckerberg, the company's co-founder and chief executive, announced Tuesday on his Facebook page that the button would be available soon, the New York Times reported on its blog.
Zuckerberg said that the "Dislike" button will show more of a shade of what a user is feeling rather than a simple option.
However, his announcement raised questions whether Facebook could become a less friendly place.
Zuckerberg said he wants to avoid the moments when someone posts a major life event on their account and someone else hits “Dislike.”
Users of the social network, which now has 1.5 billion active accounts, have long been asking for the ability to express negative emotions or empathy with something sad.
Mark Zuckerberg also said he isn't comfortable with having people "Like" current events such as the refugee crisis or the death of a family member.
"You might not feel comfortable liking that post," the Facebook representative said.
The new Facebook button hasn't been well received by everyone.
"There is already enough hate on Facebook and social media," commented Atiq Haneef from Afghanistan on the New York Times' Facebook page, where the article was posted.
"I will give 'Dislike' to the 'Dislike' button," he said.
Roger Anderson, a microbiologist from Atlanta, said there is nothing wrong with the button, encouraging people to have different opinions on Facebook.
Debra Aho Williamson, social media analyst at eMarketer, noted that it is hard to imagine that a single button can convey a complex range of negative emotions.
Moreover, she says, the election campaign in America is approaching, and the "Dislike" button would create a complete disaster.
Only 70 refugees enter Hungary in 24 hours
Hungary accepted only 70 migrants on Tuesday, a handful of the thousands who rushed to its southern border with Serbia, government adviser Gyorgy Bakondi said.

Hungary declared a state of emergency Tuesday in two counties along its border with Serbia due to the influx of refugees, closing a main border crossing and announcing it intends to build a fence along its border with Romania, DPA reports.
The move has drawn a sharp reaction from Serbia.
They said yesterday they will seal the border for people who want to cross, but not for people who want to seek asylum.
"As you can see, this is totally different," Serbian Minister for Refugees Aleksandar Vulin said.
Before the introduction of the new immigration legislation, a record number of 5,809 migrants entered Hungary on Sunday, police said on Monday.
Also, more than 170,000 migrants from the Middle East and Africa have entered Hungary from Serbia in 2015.
Many avoid being registered and try to reach Western Europe, especially Germany.
The "new" County Council headquarters is about to collapse.
Two builders in bankruptcy
Massive investments made here in recent years to relocate the institution are in danger of collapsing because they have been stopped several times.
Two major contractors working here have gone bankrupt during the construction.
The County Council headquarters on Vasile Alecsandri Street will collapse on its own.
More than a year and a half after the consolidation and refunctionalization works were supposed to be completed, the works are not even half done.

The latest twist in the saga of the building came last week, when the National Council for Solving Complaints (CNSC) rejected a complaint from the firm that wanted to take over the contract for the technical design for the remaining works.
The original project was drawn up by Impex Romcatel SA.

After the contractor went bankrupt and construction was halted, negotiations were initiated without a public call for participation with Impex Romcatel, the company being required to update the technical project, and then a new tender for works was organized.

"However, the negotiations have not resulted in a contract, with the CJ deeming the proposed form to be disadvantageous to the institution," summarized Răzvan Timofciuc, CJ's public relations representative.
The CJ decision to suspend the direct negotiations was challenged in court by Impex Romcatel.
The Iasi court sent the complaint to the CNSC, which rejected it as untimely.
This does not mean the CJ can start looking for another designer.
Impex Romcatel is allowed to challenge the CNSC decision at the Court of Appeals, only after a final sentence can we consider finding another designer.
As a result, the building's consolidation works could be resumed at the earliest next year.
Our intention is to resume work as soon as possible.
In principle, the technical project should not take long, but we have to conclude a contract.
"We are waiting to see if the CNSC decision will be appealed or not," Timofciuc said.
Works to consolidate the former police headquarters building started in 2011.
A first contract for the works was terminated in April 2012, after works worth 4.5 million lei had been carried out.
The tender was re-run and the contract was awarded to Moldoconstruct SA.
The company went bankrupt, and the contract was terminated after payments of 1.5 million lei were made.
The work has been completed by about 50%.
Initially, the works for the consolidation, refunctionalization and loft conversion of the building had been estimated at 7.7 million lei.
"Enough, I'll tell you everything!" - the statement that could incriminate the former head of Cadastre
One of the employees involved in the scandalous Cadastre Office case signed a plea agreement, for deferred sentence.
Most likely, his statements will incriminate the other defendants, led by the former head, Narciza Nedelcu
An adviser at the Cadastre and Real Estate Advertising Office (OCPI) in Iasi accused by the National Anticorruption Directorate (DNA) in a corruption file has admitted his guilt.
The plea agreement signed by Dumitru Dascălu was registered yesterday at the Iași Court, the judges deciding to issue a decision in this case on September 29.
Dumitru Daniel Dascălu was charged with continuous intellectual fraud and agreed to serve two years probation and community service.

Regarding the deeds attributed to Dascălu, prosecutors said that, as an advisor to the Cadastre Office, together with other colleagues, "he drew up several minutes of acceptance, concerning the service contracts concluded previously by O.C.P.I. Iași with the managers of the companies SC Gauss SRL, SC Grup Cinci SRL, SC Topo Euro Cad SRL, SC Agenția de Ca­dastru și Topografie SRL and PFA Lipșa Ștefan, which certified, unrealistically, the fact that the contracted services were performed in full, although in fact those were not carried out and not submitted to O.C.P.I. Iași.

Last week, the former head of the office, Narciza Nedelcu, as well as other former or current employees of the OCPI, were sent to trial in this case, accused of paying for services to the aforementioned companies, although the works were not carried out.
The damage exceeds 300,000 lei.
Adventures in the Stone Age

According to the president of the Romanian Handball Federation, Alexandru Dedu, Romania can only host a major handball competition in 2024 and the preparation of the women's national handball team for the qualification to the Olympic Games costs a fortune.
Alexandru Dedu, the president of the Romanian Handball Federation, said yesterday at a press conference that it is a great honor that our country has three teams in the Champions League groups.

As for the Romanian women's national handball team, the "main objective is to qualify for the Rio Olympics, but for this we have to pass two stages, first the World Championship and then the qualifying tournament," Dedu said.
We really want to qualify for the Olympic Games.
These are fantastic demands from the technical staff led by Tomas Ryde.
The staff will consist of seven or eight people.
He wants a second coach, a doctor, two masseurs, a goalkeepers' coach, a fitness coach and a team manager.
They asked us for things for the qualification, some physical preparation materials, that I've never heard of.
All of this to get to the Olympics. And I will do everything I can to have them.
It's a massive investment, a lot of money.
But that's the way to performance.
Because at the moment we are in the stone age with preparation.

"The teams we are competing against have this material and have had it for some time," Dedu said, adding that he is trying to obtain the necessary funds for the purchase of these items from the MTS and COSR.
The EHF president also referred to the infrastructure in Romania and the possibility of our country hosting a major handball competition.
We don't have a room in Bucharest.
It is an infrastructure problem and it is shameful to have a European gymnastics championships called into question.
Let's not forget that in other parts of the world entire Olympic villages have been built in two years.
Before 1992, the current Olympic area of Barcelona was a dump, and now it has become a beauty spot.
The same was true in London, where the 2012 Olympics were a success in terms of investments.
"In my vision, in 2024 we can host a major competition," Dedu said.
He added that the international handball bodies are willing to grant Romania the organization of a major competition.
For me it is a priority to bring major handball competitions to Romania.
Mr. Gațu went there in a civilized manner with a project, people agreed in principle, but they soon realized that the hall would never be built.

I also had talks with EHF, I told them that we want to and we can organise it, and they said they agree, and we will invite them to the first match in the new hall in Bucharest, and after that we will discuss it concretely.
"So we have the openness, both at EHF and IHF, but we don't have the infrastructure," the FRH official explained.

The former handball ace avoided to evaluate the chances of the CSM Bucharest and HCM Baia Mare women's teams to reach the Final Four: "I asked all coaches to be reserved in their predictions, because if they don't come true they will turn against them".
Clear Path to World Cup
Romanian rugby players to debut on September 23 against France

The captain of the Romanian national rugby team, Mihai Macovei, said in a press conference on Tuesday that all members of the Romanian team are ready for the matches at the World Cup in England, where they hope to obtain two victories: "We are ready".
Both me and my colleagues are on full throttle.
We trained to give our best performance in the four matches.
Everyone will have high expectations, because our goal is to win two matches, against Canada and Italy.
All groups are tough and ours is too.
Let's take it easy, first with France and then we'll see.
Certainly, if we win against Canada, the match against Italy will be our final.
I can't describe in words the joy of participating in the World Cup, it's the crowning of so many years of work.
I want not to disappoint anyone in the rugby family and to come home with some good results.
"We want you to be proud that a group of players, a small family as rugby is in Romania, proudly represents the tricolor", Macovei said.

Romania's head coach Lynn Howells, who is experiencing his first World Cup as a coach, hopes to make the Romanians proud of the national rugby team: "It is a great honour for us to participate in this World Cup".
I am sure the players are prepared to take part in the tournament.
It's an extraordinary experience for me.
For me it's very important that at every game I make Romanians proud of the national team.
Romanian Rugby Federation President Haralambie Dumitras is confident the Romanian players can confirm the progress made in recent years in rugby.
We have a very difficult group and we want to confirm the progress made by the national team.
I wish the athletes success and I am convinced that we will be up to the event.
"These boys started playing in the Romanian national team at 18-19 years old, so there's cohesion, it's a band of friends, who have set themselves to realize a dream," Dumitras said.

In the Rugby World Cup in England, Romania will play in Group D, with the following matches: with France, on September 23 in London; with Ireland, on September 27 in London; with Canada, on October 6 in Leicester; with Italy, on October 11 in Exeter.
The competition kicks off Friday at London's Twickenham Stadium with England versus Fiji in Pool A.
New Japanese Language Courses at "Al.I. Cuza" University
About the arrangement of flowers in a vase, painting in ink, but also a study of the fine arts specific to the Land of the Rising Sun you can learn at the courses organized by the students of Iasi.

The Iasi Japanese Culture Students Club is organizing new Japanese culture courses (ikebana, sumie and fine arts) in the period October 2015 - June 2016, courses for both beginners and seasoned people.
They will take place at the European Studies Center of "Al. I. Cuza" University in Iasi and are organized in order to promote Japanese arts and culture, both traditional and modern.
There is a single participation fee of 50 lei per person per month.
In addition to art classes, participants will be able to take part in exhibitions and other cultural activities to promote beauty.
The Japanese culture courses that we have proposed are designed as an invitation for the general public to take the first steps on the road to self-knowledge through art.

"Interested people will be able to learn how to make harmonious floral sculptures (ikebana), how to capture the soul of the surroundings in plastic compositions using the Japanese art of painting in ink (Sumie) or how to express their own individuality and creativity through the multivalent universe of fine arts (graphic, drawing, painting)," said Sorin Mazilu, the teacher of these courses.
The courses are open to anyone passionate about art, regardless of age or experience.
Registration will take place until September 30 and those who want more information can call 0742.027.153 or e-mail studenticultura@gmail.com.
14 million lei given to 'St. Spiridon' Hospital in Iasi at budget adjustment
What will be purchased with this large sum of money?
The "St. Spiridon" Hospital received from the Ministry of Health, following the budget amendment, about 14 million lei.

The money the medical unit received to use until the end of the year will be invested in modernization and development work at several clinics, as well as in medical equipment and technology for which the hospital has already started the public procurement procedure.

Therefore, the medical unit will be equipped with a new computer tomograph, a new radiology device, six sets used for surgical interventions, six intensive care beds, an ophthalmological microscope and other necessary devices for medical practice.
On the other hand, 5 million lei from the money received by the hospital will be directed to the construction and renovation of the "Great Art".
From the budget rectification, UPU will receive 500,000 lei to finish the modernization works in the main section.

"In addition, in the coming days we will receive the works of the walkway linking the ACCU to the cardiology, hepatology and gastroenterology clinics in order to ensure decent transport of the patient from the ACCU to the neighboring clinics," the hospital manager also explained.
Soon the hospital will have in its yard the Dermatology Clinic of Tătărași, which it will organize as an outpatient clinic, under the same form as it currently functions.
The clinic will operate in the area where the allergology, hematology and endocrinology departments are located in the outpatient clinic and will have about 30 beds.
Iași made a laughing stock by RATP controllers and a leaflet.
A Tourist’s Misfortune
A family of tourists from Cluj came to Iasi to visit him, but the trip ended with a bitter promise.
After the experience we had, neither my wife nor myself want to ever set foot in your city again.
They bumped into wrong information from leaflets, insensitivity from RAPT controllers and, bonus, a fine "because it is the law".
The couple arrived in Iasi a few days ago, checked into a hotel in the city center and asked for tourist brochures.
They also received a leaflet with the RATP routes.
Armed with these maps, the couple visited Iasi.
But two days ago, in Copou, they wanted to get to Palas Mall.
Because there was no ticket machine at the station near Copou Park, they relied on the information printed on the leaflet: that they could buy a ticket by SMS.
No one told them that the service no longer exists.
Confident in the leaflet, they boarded a bus and tried to send an SMS according to the instructions on the leaflet.
Unfortunately for them, a team of RATP controllers showed up.
They said that the service has not existed for 2 years and that it has been announced in the press that it has been canceled.
HOW SHOULD I KNOW what was written in the local press, me coming the night before to visit the city?
I talked to the controllers, I explained the situation, they said they didn't care, it's not their business.
His attitude was very defiant.
They said that all they can do is give us a single fine instead of two (for me and my wife).
"I paid, I didn't want to waste my day by going to the police station and giving statements there!", says Ovidiu.
The family was fined because of the erroneous information on the brochure and the controllers who "applied the law to the letter".
It is not correct, and I made a complaint to the RATP Iasi to get my money back.
It's not about the money, it's not a lot, but the idea is that I felt cheated.
Bad luck for Vaslui rapists.
They had an accident and remained in preventive detention
The trial of the seven rapists from Vaslui was moved yesterday to the Court of Appeal in Iași.
The magistrates in Iasi have held the first court session in a closed hearing in which the seven young people accused of humiliating an 18-year-old girl have asked to be freed.
Before the start of the trial, one of the three Iasi judges who was assigned the case, Viorel Munteanu, submitted a request to recuse himself, which was accepted by his colleagues on the bench.

The magistrate worked until this summer at the Vaslui Court, where he was the President of the Criminal Section, being the one who, on April 9, admitted a complaint brought by four of the accused, ordering their placement under house arrest.
The case is currently being heard by a panel of judges comprising Maricica Mititelu and Geta Sandu.
Earlier, Judge Dan Anton recused himself from the case because his daughter was in a relationship with one of the rapists' lawyers.
The two judges decided the Vaslui rapists will stay in custody.
The youths will remain in custody for at least another 30 days, when judges will reconsider the possibility of releasing them.
The next hearing will take place at the Iasi Court of Appeal on October 6.
Before reaching the Iasi Court of Appeal, the van carrying the rapists from Vaslui was involved in an accident in the Păcurari neighbourhood, the car entering Iasi on the beltway.
The Iveco van carrying the seven rapists hit a Volkswagen car that was coming out of Canta Street and the driver tried to turn left.
The van was driving from the Păcurari end.
The car entered Iasi through here because the Penitentiary Administration employees preferred the route from Vaslui to Iasi through Grajduri, then on the ring road.
They thus shortened the road by a few kilometers.
Immediately after the crash, the prisoners' escort called for another transport to pick up the detainees.
Shortly after, a car from the Maximum Security Prison in Iasi was dispatched to the scene and the seven inmates were transported to the Court of Appeal.
No one was injured in the crash.
To transfer them to the other van, guards surrounded the back of the vehicles, and the detainees came out quickly, two by two.

"The incident was not reported to the police because the drivers of the two vehicles have agreed amicably about the damage to be paid," said Chief Commissioner Mădălin Țăranu, from the County Police Inspectorate.
Great migrations
Romania is not and will not be prepared for what is to come.
But Europe?

I will say from the onset, clearly and directly: the some 7,000 refugees that Romania should and must naturalize represent, in itself, an insignificant number, but a huge number in comparison to the capacity of the Romanian state to manage such a project.
Even the voluntary quota proposed by Bucharest, of around 1500 souls, far exceeds the good intentions of solidarity with the European Union expressed in recent months.
Certainly, if those migrants really agree to settle in our localities, the chances to quickly integrate them into the Romanian society are extraordinarily small.
I'm sure they will be the first to lose patience.
Infested with mobsters and paralyzed by a venal political class, the Romanian state has proved impotent in all areas.
The inability to integrate gypsies is just a banal example.

In addition, governments of every color have been unable to absorb EU funds, build roads, kindergartens or modern schools, provide decent medical care, clean up the streets, create decently paid jobs or keep their own young generation at home.
Why would refugees settle in another country they are fleeing from?
But what is most surprising is the hypocrisy with which such a crisis is being treated.
We are first faced with the belligerent hypocrisy of the powerful countries of the EU, which show maximum generosity when it comes to sharing the afflictions with smaller countries.

Then comes the cowardly hypocrisy of the Romanians who, although they have millions of relatives scattered all over the world, still cannot accept the other - of another language, another religion, another blood.
Probably for fear that someone would steal their national being.

Finally, there is the hypocrisy of many migrants who, although they invoke the horrors of war as their motive for leaving, do not accept any destination for their exodus other than Germany or the Nordic countries.
But not all refugees are Syrian, and there is no war in Pakistan.
Also, the simplistic way in which the crisis is analyzed can only be ridiculed.
Some call for the causes to be eliminated and, betting strictly on the book of political correctness, they call for peace and investment in the countries of origin of migrants.
But in Romania there is peace and even some foreign capital sometimes comes into the national economy - but that does not stop tens of thousands of Romanians leaving their country every year.
Why are they leaving?
In the crisis, the European Union has revealed itself as a rigid, divided and outdated construction.
I lamented the fact that Romania is unable to invent a project for the country, but it turns out that the EU does not have a plan for the future either.
And improvisations and threats don't help anything.
So what is the point of the EU if the one advantage Romanians had - the right to free movement - could be put in question because of the waves of refugees that are crossing borders like cheese?
At some point, the war in Syria will end.
Not the migrant crisis.
In the coming decades, overpopulation, poverty, climate change, resource depletion, etc. will drive millions of desperate migrants, mostly from Asia and especially Africa, toward a better life.
With such politicians, Romania is not and will never be prepared for what is to come.
7,000 euros per year to rent Pogor Club.
Forced Destination
The concession tender is for a 10-year period.
After 7 years in which it remained closed, the club in the courtyard of the Romanian Literature Museum is offered by the County Council for concession for a period of 10 years.
The construction has a useful area of 134 square meters, on two levels of basements.
The court accepts as destinations for the building only those of literary cafe, bookstore or other cultural activities.
The building was appraised at 68,300 euros, with the starting bid of 6,830 euros a year, with a bid increment of 25 euros.

The concessionaire will have to exploit the building continuously and permanently and to cover in full the costs of rehabilitating the building, in accordance with the technical project to be drawn up.

"The Pogor Club building is in an advanced state of degradation due to the fact that during the period when this space was occupied by the catering unit and even after its evacuation, no current repair and maintenance works were carried out, as are necessary during the exploitation of a building," the documentation relevant to the tender procedure states.
Bids for the club's concession are expected by September 18.
Two brothers from Tomești swallowed sleeping pills.
They were taken to hospital
Two brothers, aged 9 and 11, from Tomești have swallowed several Diazepam pills.
They found the pills in the house and took them out of curiosity.
Their mother was undergoing treatment, and the medicines were not hidden.
The children were rushed to the "Sfânta Maria" hospital in Iași.
They are in stable condition, doctors say.
EXCLUSIVE: A heart-breaking meeting.
At 20, She Got a Brave Gift: Her Biological Parents

Lost in the hospital in unclear conditions in the dark of the 90s, when she was only two months old, small, sick and helpless, and then adopted by a wealthy family from Italy, in the same years when adoption was vaguely regulated, a young woman from Iasi, now a beautiful blonde girl, reunited yesterday in Iasi with her biological parents from a village in the county, after almost two decades in which no one knew anything about each other.
Crina will turn 20 this year, and her adoptive parents from Palermo decided to offer their beloved daughter a wonderful and courageous gift: a trip to Romania, to Iasi, to know her unclear past.
"Ziarul de Iași", which has assisted in the search for the family of origin after a few extremely vague clues, was witness to these meetings, which practically break your heart.
The reporters' account, the emotions of the moment, the statements of those involved, their reactions are truly moving and overwhelming.
Crina's story begins 20 years ago in the Iasi village of Ruginoasa, when she was only two months old.
Then, because of a health problem, the girl had to be hospitalized in the city.
At home there began to be disagreements between parents, and the mother was forced to leave home.
He decided to keep the girl and send me home.
He stopped the girl, and since then I have not heard anything.
"When I found out she was in hospital, it was too late," Alina, the girl's biological mother, recalls sadly.
Crina was hospitalized along with her grandmother at the municipal hospital in Pascani, while the girl's father, Costica Balcan, left to work in the city of Alexandria, Teleorman County.
Their lives were to part forever.
They couldn't find Crina at the hospital
After his daughter's hospitalization, her father went to work in another town, and returned after six months.
Meanwhile, the girl was transferred to the hospital in Iasi, and when the father returned, he could not find her.
I think it was almost nine months since the girl had been in the hospital.
"She must have thought she was abandoned," a granddaughter of the family says.
Due to financial problems, the grandmother could not come to Iasi with Crina, and the girl remained in the care of doctors.

Since no one has been interested in the child's fate in all this time, she was taken over by the General Directorate for Social Assistance and Child Protection Iasi, which then gave her to the care of Bucium Placement Center.
Those were the years when abandonment and adoption were more loosely regulated in Romania than they are today.
The Bucium Centre was found by the Italian Salvadore and his wife, a couple from Palermo who wanted to have their child but they couldn't.
They fell in love with the blonde Crina, and after some time she would move permanently with them to Italy.
The little girl was already almost two, the time it took to complete the adoption formalities.
When I saw Crina, I felt like she was our daughter.
"As if my wife gave her life," says Salvadore, the adoptive father, smiling as he holds the frail girl's hand in his.
Back home, Crina's parents, Alina and Costică, continued the search separately, each in their own way.
The father asked the authorities in Ruginoasa, but received no answer as to where his child could be.
Police then told them that it was possible she was dead, but in Iasi, the parents found out what had really happened to their daughter.
When I looked for her here, they told me at the Tribunal that she had gone to Italy, to Palermo.
And I didn't have any conditions to look for it.
We prayed to God that everything would be okay.
I was thinking about her all these years, but there were no possibilities to look for her, to find her.
"It's hard," Crina's biological mother tells us with tears in her eyes.
But even though the years have passed, the parents in Ruginoasa have not been forgotten.
In Italy, Salvadore and his wife explained to their daughter where she came from, and that her past is tied to Romania.
I was young when I found out.
I think I was five or six years old.
I reacted like a child, I was curious.
"I wanted to meet my parents from Romania," Crina said happily.
And her dream was about to come true.

In March this year, chief commissioner Romica Ichim, director of the Iasi Regional Centre for Drug Prevention, Assessment and Counselling, was contacted by an acquaintance in Italy, who explained to him Salvadore's desire to find Crina's biological family.
And the searches began with just one name.
After the request we had from our partners in Italy, we started the first steps.
I had only a name, Balcan Costică, then the village, Ruginoasa.
Shortly thereafter I had activity with the municipality there, and I was able to ask if there was the given name in the area.
They gave me a few pointers, but the person they found was not the one I was looking for.
"It took us a month to find the biological father of the girl," explains Chief Commissioner Romică Ichim.
It took the authorities more than three months to find Costică and Alina, especially since each had a residence in a different locality.
We started the procedure in March and we finalized the identification of the biological parents and the discussions in June-July.
"We decided that the first meeting should take place in September," Romica Ichim said.
Last weekend, Alina and Costică saw their lost daughter for the first time in 20 years in the halls of the hospital in Iași.
The father, emotional, could barely hold back his tears and his hands trembled incessantly.
He barely exchanged words with those around him.
A week before the meeting he could barely sleep.
He was all excited, trembling.
"It's something to see your child after so many years," says a granddaughter, who also came with Costică from Ruginoasa.
Crina's Meeting with Her Biological Mother and Brother

In his conversation with his daughter, who is going to study at a well-ranked university in Italy, Costică Balcan told her, among other things, that if she ever wants to come back to him, in the village, to come quietly: he can give her some sheep, goats, so that she can find a boy from the village and start a household.
The mother is also emotional, crying, and she can hardly believe that this could happen to her.
I'm very excited.
I didn't think it could happen.
I've seen such cases on television, I've thought about it all these years, I've hoped, but I never thought it might happen to me.
There is a lot of emotion.
If he could forgive me.
I hope we will visit each other in the future.
'I hope we can keep in touch,' says Alina, Crina's mother, with tears in her eyes as she holds a handkerchief tightly.
