He hides his tears of joy, because soon he will see his daughter after so much bitterness.
On the other hand, Crina, who will turn 20 this month, tries to calm herself down like an emotional child.
She doesn't know what to expect, but she has a vague idea about her biological parents.
He thinks they are young, but now before the meeting he tries to gather his thoughts, because he has a lot to say, but nothing to reproach.
My parents are two mothers and two fathers.
But my parents are the ones who raised me.
It will be a beautiful meeting, a wonderful experience.
"I hope I have a nice memory with them, because now there are so many things to say," Crina says.
First family reunion in Iași
At Unirii Square, under the early autumn skies, the family from Ruginoasa reunites its destiny with their daughter from Palermo.
Crina is now 20 years old, finishing high school, after the Italian school model, but she can now start a new chapter with Alina and Costică, her biological parents.
They are no longer separated by borders or countries, but only by a barrier: language.
Over which, with the help of a translator, an Italian owner of a bar in the center of Iași, passed easily.
Those who made the meeting possible say it's the first such event, and if the opportunity arises again, they would do it again.
This is the first event of this kind and I'm glad it is a success.
Here at the Center we have different activities, and most of the time we are associated as being an institution that deals only with consumers and people addicted to drugs.
But we are trying to give something good back to society.
"If I am asked for such an event again, I will do it with great pleasure," smiles Romica Ichim, the director of the Iasi Regional Center for Drug Prevention, Assessment and Counseling.
Behind them, the Balcan family, with Crina in the middle, walks away telling stories.
It's understandable: they have a lot to tell each other.
There were armed truces, yesterday, at PSD.
Everyone is taking a breather
The factions within PSD's Iasi branch have reached an armistice with guns in hand.
After successive rounds of talks, from Friday through Sunday, the first of which was the most tense, PSD leaders agreed to temporarily suspend hostilities.
Pressed by the party's executive president, Liviu Dragnea, to present a united position, the Social Democrats in Iasi will send him a full list of potential candidates for party positions.
Far from being over, the internal war in the party appears to have taken only a pause to allow combatants to catch their breath.
Dragnea did not give an ultimatum.
He launched a very simple and very current message given the current situation: try to find a solution to not put the party at risk.
On October 3rd we have elections in the party.
All positions will be made available to those who want them.
"Until then, we will remain in the existing structure," interim mayor Mihai Chirica said.
The two days of talks over the weekend only yielded the conclusion that nothing was decided.
At the elections in October, a fierce competition is expected for the position of president of the county branch of the PSD.

The shortlist of potential candidates for the party's top position in Iasi includes State Secretary Maricel Popa, Senator Florin Constantinescu, Senator Sorin Lazăr, County Councilor Vasile Câtea, and Interim County Council President Victorel Lupu.
The list might also include the mayor of Schitu Duca, Mihai Mihalache.
Another option is that of the leader of the PSD county councilors, Cristian Stanciu, in case Lupu will not join in the race, sources within the party saying that he is not interested in the position.
The only name that has not been mentioned by any of the participants in the negotiations over the past few days is that of the former leader of the party's local branch, Mayor Gheorghe Nichita.
The list of candidates is open.
By statute, even on election day candidates can be filed, and it will not surprise anyone if it happens.

"It is important that we stay united and we will remain united even after October 3, when we will have a new Executive Bureau, a new County Permanent Bureau and all the new leadership structures," Câtea said.
Until the organization of the internal elections, the county branch of the PSD will be led by Victorel Lupu, a close associate of Nichita and Stanciu.

However, Lupu is on vacation until September 29, with the election preparations being taken care of by the executive secretary of the branch, the county councilor Mihail Popescu, who is on good terms with the Nichita camp.
Reached by telephone, Cristian Stanciu said that talks over the last few days have led to "partial consensus".
There is a wide availability to maintain balance and unity in the party.
A partial consensus was reached to support a unified team to handle the county.
"On the other hand, there are several versions regarding the intentions to run for the PSD Iasi presidency, the list remaining open", Stanciu commented.
An Iași magistrate rejects the Vaslui rapists' case on the grounds of concubinage
The seven young men from Vaslui sentenced for rape will arrive at the Court of Appeal in Iasi today.

The Vaslui convicts sentenced to between five years and eight months and eight years and four months will today present their arguments on being released, after the trial court, Vaslui County Court, ruled for their immediate imprisonment after the sentencing.
The case was filed with the appeals court last week, with Judge Dan Anton filing a request for recusal, which was granted by his colleagues.
Anton cited the fact that one of the defendants' lawyers, Bogdan Luca, is the live-in partner of his daughter, lawyer Dana Anton.
Luca is defending Silviu Ovidiu Burada, who received the longest sentence in this case.
How the judge justified the sentence
Last week, the Vaslui county court judge who sentenced the seven youths explained his verdict.
In his ruling, the judge talked about the defiant attitude of the defendants and those who supported them, saying such behavior creates a strong sense of indignation among the public.

"The court notes that after the placing under the measure of judicial control, a restrictive measure of liberty but not a deprivation of liberty, under the impact of the attitude of the defendants, their families and local supporters, it was felt at the level of the local and national community a strong sense of indignation regarding the fact that people accused of serious offenses are judged under a less restrictive measure," the Vaslui Court said in its motivation.
The magistrates also dismissed the main defense of the seven defendants who had argued during the trial that the girl they raped was not a "church door".

"The tribunal highlights that it is irrelevant the moral quality of the victim, a fact that the defendants wanted to emphasize in their defenses, as the physical and sexual freedom of a person cannot be violated under any pretext," the decision reads.
Corbyn, Brexit and the future of Europe
For economic and demographic reasons, the prosperity enjoyed over the last decades cannot continue in the same way in the years to come.
Until Saturday, few people in Romania probably knew who Jeremy Corbyn was.

Even today, after he has become the new leader of Britain's Labour Party, many are asking to what extent the election of a politician who, after all, is not in a position of decision-making power can affect us.
Jeremy Corbyn is the most left-wing Labour leader since the war.

An avowed Marxist, anti-monarchist (he once asked then prime minister Tony Blair to move the Royal Family out of Buckingham Palace), a fierce anti-American and a supporter of Vladimir Putin (he was regularly invited to comment on political events by the Russian TV channel Russia Today), and of the terrorist movements Hezbollah and Hamas, he wants Britain to give up its nuclear weapons and leave NATO and the EU.
For Corbyn, who at the time called the killing of Osama bin Laden a tragedy, ISIS is almost preferable to the United States.
Like all populist demagogues, Corbyn, of course, has miraculous anti-austerity solutions.
The kind of things that Tsipras was saying and promising in Greece until he came face to face with the real world and the economic realities.
The Labour leader's economic program includes, among other things, massive re-nationalisations and printing money to fund development projects and pay for very generous social benefits.
Of course, some may ask why the printing money solution is not universally adopted across the globe, we would then have global prosperity!, but who cares about such details.

Sure, we can tax the bankers, who have become the left's bogeymen, but as we've seen so many times in the past, not just in the former communist states or in Ecuador or Venezuela, but also in France, at the beginning of the terms of Mitterand and Hollande.
The extra money is quickly swallowed up by the generous, unfunded promises made by populist demagogues.
As Margaret Thatcher famously said, "the problem with socialism is that eventually you run out of other people's money".
Few give Jeremy Corbyn any real chance of ever becoming prime minister.
In the early 1980s, another left-wing radical, Michael Foot, who was not as extreme in his convictions as the new party leader, failed miserably in the elections.
And then there was still a working class in Britain, in the classic sense of the word, relatively substantial and structured.
And unions were far more influential than they are now.
In the new industrial landscape, in which services dominate the workforce and extensive automation has reduced the need for low-skilled labor in industry, Corbyn’s rhetoric has limited appeal.
But even in opposition, he can influence important developments that can directly affect us.
In its latest issue Financial Times considers that Corbyn's election increases the chances of Brexit, that is Britain's exit from the EU.
The new Labour leader has been a consistent opponent of the country's membership in the EU.
In the eyes of the radical left, Brussels is the agent of international capitalism and a promoter of globalization that has imposed austerity on the poor.

When you combine such ideas with those expressed by the radical right, with anti-immigration rhetoric, and look at the refugee crisis that is shaking the foundations of the EU, you get an explosive mixture.
And not just for Britain.

But if the British decide in a referendum due by 2017 to leave the EU, the loss of symbolic capital for the entire European project and the deep fissures within it created by the euro crisis and now the refugee crisis, between north and south, east and west, leave room for the most worrying scenarios.
All the more so because for a whole series of member states, London was a counterweight to the Franco-German axis (in which in any case Berlin is increasingly becoming the dominant actor).
It's true, the British business community, the City, are strong advocates of the country remaining in the EU.
But today's Europe is not the Europe of the past.
There's a lot of resentment, which is growing in intensity even in these weeks.

The problem is that Brussels, we've seen recently in Jean Claude Juncker's speech, tends more and more to take major decisions over the head of the great majority of the member states by consulting only a few European powers, mostly Germany.
This is happening as support for anti-establishment, anti-immigration parties that are also eurosceptic is growing spectacularly across the continent.
In other words, the negative emotional climate has reached higher levels than ever before.
This is the conclusion the Financial Times reaches when evaluating the chances of Brexit.
The pro-EU option is based on a cold calculation that starts from the national interest.
If voters take the cerebral decision, then Britain will stay in the EU.
But Corbyn's victory reminds us of the power of emotion in contemporary politics.
But Eastern Europe can be significantly affected by such major developments.

Especially if, as expected, we will see a more pronounced integration of the Eurozone, which will push most of the region's states to the periphery of both interest and decision-making processes in Europe.
Corbyn, Tsipras and Syriza in Greece, Podemos in Spain, even Bernie Sanders in the United States are all feeding populist rhetoric from the frustrations accumulated in Western societies.
Because of economic and demographic factors, the prosperity enjoyed in the last few decades, the generous social benefits, cannot continue in the same way in the years to come.

Under the explosive pressure of the dual crisis, Euro Zone - immigration, both caused by hasty decisions that have taken into account only the integrationist political ambitions and not the ability and willingness of the people and the governments in Europe to respond to such challenges, the turbulence on the continent, the internal tensions in the EU will increase in intensity and can affect the situation of Romania.
And it's hard to exclude anything from the point of view of possible scenarios.
The question is whether our main political leaders are able to deal with such complicated situations.
Constantin Brâncuși, the peasant god.
Rockefeller: "How can I help you?"
Brâncuși: "Go and sweep the workshop!"
The great sculptor had a great dream: to be somebody, to become famous, to be heard about all over the world.
But behind his fame lies something almost forgotten today, when we are delivered millions of success stories, recipes for success in life.
That something has a name.
It's called "trudă".
What to write about Constantin Brâncuși?
What else is there to say, actually?
His face has appeared on banknotes.
And, recently, a well-known bank in Romania hired an actor to play him in an advertisement.
Brâncuși is still producing and delivering money almost 60 years after his death.
In Romania, there are hundreds of streets and boulevards that bear his name.
Indeed, even the author of this text lives on one of these streets.
And when she goes out with the child, she hears the following instructions: "We're going to the park, to Brâncuși".
The country is dotted with his statues.
There are few Romanian personalities whose works are known by so many people, from children to the elderly.
Brancusi's infiltration capacity is huge.
Even the communists didn't manage to eradicate him from the memory and culture of Romania.
His quotes are now all over the internet, receiving hundreds of thousands of likes and shares.
And then, again, what else is there to say, to write about this man?
Seen from the heap of books and articles that attempt to reconstruct his destiny, Brancusi's life seems almost fantastic, totally improbable.
You know, those people who tell you that if you weren't lucky enough to be born in a big city and in a relatively well-off family, your chances of success in life are almost nil.
Brancusi's life is the perfect counter-example.
And that may be a key.
Perhaps this is where the following text should begin.
With a sentence, however despicable it may be.
Forget the stupid success stories that are fed to you daily in newspapers and on television.
Take a good look at the face of this man.
Do you want to know how he managed to succeed in life, how, today, the whole world heard of him?
It's simple.
He worked all his life to be somebody.
He did.
Constantin Brâncuși was born on February 19, 1876, in Hobita, a small village in the commune of Peștișani, Gorj County, at the foothills of the Carpathians.
He is the fifth child of Maria and Radu Nicolae Brâncuși.
Although he came from a wealthy peasant family, Brancusi led a modest life, from which he was to gather the landmarks that would guide his late artistic vision.
Remembering his childhood and the places where he grew up, the artist would confess, in a meeting with Petre Țuțea, in Paris, in 1933: "Back then, life was beautiful and harmonious."
For millennia, people were living a happy patriarchal life.
Everything was going smoothly from season to season.
And you know why things have changed?
The great city civilization has reached us.
Brancusi's childhood was far from idyllic, however.
One event in these early years is extremely suggestive of the combination of purity and violence that characterized the future sculptor's years spent in his native locality.
The moment is reproduced in the book "Brâncuși. A Biography", written by Alexandru Buican.
In 1879, Constantin Brâncuși was 3 years old.

In the fall of that year, when the brandy was being made, Brancusi was keeping an eye on the people tasting the liquid to see if the process was going well, but he caught a moment of general inattention.
He fills his palms with brandy and drinks it in one gulp.
He falls asleep almost instantly.
The first people notice only after a few minutes.
The mother goes into panic, then hysteria, believing her son has died.
In the evening, when father Radu returns from the vineyard, accompanied by musicians, he sees the desperate signs of those who are waiting for him with bated breath.
The party immediately turns into mourning.
The father is already thinking about the funeral.
Still, somebody finds it good to call her Baba Brândușa, a doctor and servant of Brâncuși.
Brândușa checks the child's breathing, then places some horse manure under his nose.
The child sneezes loudly.
The world applauds.
While the boy is left to sleep off his drunkenness, the gypsy party continues with even more force.
The next day, the father and son meet in the orchard.
Radu Brâncuși asks Constantin to collect some willow branches and bring them to him.
The father puts the child upside down and, with the twigs brought by the boy, he beat him to remember.
And, while feeling the sting of the blows, little Brancusi has the revelation that the world can be viewed from a different perspective and that things around him can appear upside down.
Especially the sun's position, different from the one he is familiar with, makes him wonder, as he would admit in his old age, whether the very star was involved in his turmoil.
Had the sun been as troubled as his father by what had happened to him?
The city is not working right now.
A lawmaker calls on politicians to remember those who voted for them.
Independent deputy Viorel Blajut called on the PSD and PNL to stop the internal fighting and reorient their agenda toward the electorate.
What we are seeing now on our political stage is a great divide and that's it.
I haven't seen any of the 2012 USL projects being continued.
No highway, no regional emergency hospital, just politicians fighting over possible locations based on real estate interests.
Let's put politics aside for a moment, get together and talk.
The city is not functioning at the moment.
"If you are busy with an internal war, you don't have time for the people who elected you," Blajut said.

He said the current political class has disappointed the Iasi electorate, and the consequence will be a low turnout in the upcoming local elections, around 30%, representing the loyal electorate of the parties.
The deputy also believes that voters will turn to the traditional parties, expressing reservations about new political initiatives, such as the "For Iasi" party, which will be launched today.
Local parties have little chance and will only split the right-wing vote, not the PSD's.
Such parties rely on active civic people, who are usually right-wing.
"The right is becoming even more fragmented, which is not good for anyone, not even for the PSD," Blajut said.
He said he was not interested in running for office in the upcoming local elections, denying rumors that he would run for mayor.
I have said that I do not want to run for any local office.
I'm still thinking whether I should continue as a deputy in the next term.
I tried to appeal to unity for Iasi and in discussions on the hallways, with other parliamentarians, and I was accused that I want to make an image of myself.
I don't want to, but we can't go on like this.

"If people voted for us, it doesn't mean they are stupid to vote for us again if they don't see anything," Blajut said, adding that the main reason why voters are no longer interested in politics is the hypocrisy of the elected officials.
A colleague from Tătărași said that he doesn't have enough money and he has to go by bus.
Let's not be hypocrites.
It's not a small amount of money.
Sometimes I'm ashamed to pick up the money from the cashier.
At the end of the term I will make a report on all that I spent, besides the salaries of the staff of the cabinet and its maintenance.
I managed to raise 30,000 lei in a month, with all the transportation, accommodation and other expenses accounted for.
"It's pure hypocrisy for a parliamentarian to say that he doesn't have enough money", Blăjuț concluded.
